number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												There are so many things about this game that I enjoy, and I wish it wasn't over so fast. Replayability comes through branching story threads and community content, but I still want more. The writing is razor-sharp and full of genuine wit and sarcasm, with the occasional breaking of the fourth wall to comment on gaming conventions. The art is simple but effective, using its minimal tech to create a convincing mood. The jazzy soundtrack is perfect for the story. And while its particular selling point of rewiring the building around you as you sneak through it wasn't implemented as well as it could have been, it still makes for some highly elaborate, complex solutions to puzzles at times. Everything about it was a treat, and I didn't have any complaints but for its fairly short running time. This is one of my highest recommendations when it comes to indie games.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												When I bought this, I had no idea what I'm going into.I found pure awesomeness.Gunpoint is a 2D stealth game about breaking into secure buildings, rewiring things and punching people. It says that in the description, and for once, the game description doesn't lie to you. It's exactly about that. However, it's unbelievable how much fun can you have with it.You are playing as Richard Conaway, a freelance hacker. Your usual job is to steal and sell sensitive data. But to achieve that, you first need to get to the terminals the data's in. How do you do that? Using a couple interesting gadgets, of course!The first gagdets you get are Bullfrog Hypertrousers and a Longfall Coat. With only the ability to jump very high, survive falls and climb walls, this basic equipment lets you complete a few missions before you gain access to the Crosslink Device.Crosslink allows you to rewire things - Locked door? Hang on, let me just link this light switch to it and open it. Camera linked to an alarm? No worries, we'll just disconnect that. And it gets even crazier - How about stunning your enemies using power sockets? Or remotely shoot their own guns? Right into the back of another guard?This puzzle system is incredibly fun to use and surprisingly simple to understand. You can't fight the guards head-on, but you can turn their lights off, wait for them to open the locked door, connect it to a motion sensor, walk trough and have it close just in time to knock them out. Or just run into it and use the Gatecrasher device to kick the door open in such it throws the guard out of the window behind. Later on, the levels get more complex, multiple Crosslink nets are set up without being connected into eachother, your enemies get body armors, can see in dark... yet you can still outsmart them in multiple ways, which lets you play the game how you want.But it gets even better. The game has a beautiful soundtrack, which perfectly suits the atmosphere, a great noir-ish atmosphere, and a great sense of humor even when you're being held at Gunpoint. It also features one of the best achievements I've ever seen. Anywhere.In the end, the only thing you'll be sad about in this game is how short it is. The campaign provides only about 150 minutes of fun and brilliant story. Luckily, the game supports Steamworks and has Level Editor - this combination can provide numerous hours of fun.If you haven't played this yet, then I recommend doing so. Otherwise you'll missing one of the greatest puzzle masterpieces in the history of video games. Seriously.

												A short game, but I found it worth the money thanks to the constant sass options available. Most games don't have your character glibly text his contacts the bracketed notes you assume are for your own benefit.The puzzles are engaging, tricky, and combat is hilariously satisfying. The game is somewhat dynamic and you can play for most sides like any true espionage agent. You can play like a consumate professional, or you can be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with spring-loaded pants and an itchy punching fist.The only real downside is that in the end, it all boils down to a single ending. It's an ending you can handle several different ways, but it's the same one, really.Protip: Don't get too fancy when you clear the final level for the first time, save whatever battery you have, because whatever you have at the end is how much battery you have for any post-game easter egg hunting you might want to do. (Unless you plan to restart the entire game from zero, in which case, go ahead.)

												This is a game where you play as a spy who can hack into devices in a building that you're infiltrating. The spy can also burst out of windows and beat guards up. The fun comes when you're hacking though, and you can do stuff like electrify a socket that a guard is standing next to or confuse a guard by turning off a light. Now I'm not saying I'm better than anybody but when a light gets turned off I don't get confused and start pacing the room like a weirdo but this is a video game I think. Anyway, the writing is actually competent for a video game and there's a lot of options as to how you tackle a level. Only problem is that this game is kinda short but there's Steam Workshop support and a level editor. Also, knocking out guards by remotely opening a door in their face is great fun, and you can do it in this game as well as in real life.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2013
												Cheap and fun. That's what an Indie game should be. Gunpoint is both of those things. Gunpoint is a pixellated action/strategy combination that goes together better than bacon and literally anything else you could think of. The text presented dialogue is funny and the gameplay is fastpaced and entertaining. Deaths...and there will be many of them...let you restart the game from literally seconds before you made the mistake so you never feel bad for trying something interesting and failing badly. And Gunpoint is one of those games where failure is half the fun.Using a variety of tools, you can hack doors, tackle guards, and perform a whole slew of complex or simple tricks to outwit your enemies and complete your objectives. The levels are diverse and varied, and the gameplay, which is very simple, never grows boring nor seems repetitious. ---Rags' Rating - The Maltese Shiba  / 10

content:

												To me, Gunpoint is a true example of pixel art, it exelently blends the story, style of gameplay and mechanics together,if you read the dialog (which most people i guess dont) you'll find that the story is really well written, its a really little stealth game and when the campaign finishes you will be begging for more, thats where the LEVEL EDITOR comes in, also if you're like me you will want to finish all of the achievements, ive read a few review before i bought this game and they said to buy this game while its on sale, but i didnt and really DO NOT regret it, its currently my FAVORET game, and i also cant wait for the developer (Tom Francis) to get his new game "Heat signature" out on steam..Pros:-VERY well written story.-Exelent mechanics.-Nice pixel art style.-Level editor.-Cheap and pleasing.-To me its worth the price.However the ONLY 2 cons are :-No workshop integration (coming soon though).-No CO-OP.If this game had these 2 feutures, then it will be a bestseller...This game is a MUST HAVE if you're a fan of platformers....and if you arent, then this game will MAKE you one.Update: The developer has announced that workshop integration will be added, but he isnt sure when the update will be released because he's planning on porting Gunpoint to another engine, also, alot of people say this game is over priced, it is NOT.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Another excelent noir themed masterpiece. This game design is so inteligent, well thought, that this premisse could make an AAA successful game easily. Wait a sec... yeah, Watchdogs! Now that I thought about it, this game is like a Watchdogs 2d, except this one here came earlier and is more awesome on its own way. I mean, this game did not need to be a $50+, super graphics, "open world" to be a bad♥♥♥♥♥innovative game. PS, Watchdogs fans: I'm just kidding, guys. Watchdogs seems pretty good aswell, even though I still have not played. Also, they are definitely different games with only good similarities.Back to review:The levels on this game are perfectly designed to improve the difficulty more and more and the learning curve of your "hacking powers" is great. Challenges you will face includes lasers, armed guards, sensors, alarms, doors, noise, police, etc. Think of this game like Mission: Impossible 1 (the very best).Good gameplay is good. Innovative. You need to plan every movement, wire ("hack") the right cables on the right moment to close a door over a unarmed guard, or to keep an armed one stucked in a room. You can buy a lot of upgrades aswell, like, for instance, a cloak for jumping across glass without making noise, or upgrades on your pants to jump higher.The story also has a good part here. Is great, fun, intriguing and yet light and casual. Each level is a mission that you receive as a job from secret employers. More than one time you will need to make a choice, take sides, etc. The payment for mission completion is what lets you buy new stuff and upgrades. Don't fear this game. The title might be misleading but it's not a 90's shooter, its more like a stealth game 2d. I recommend this game to pretty much everyone, since awesomeness is meant for everyone. You'll have a good time with this and replayability grants you another few fun hours if you wanna see all the endings and/or if you are an achievement hunter.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2013
												Gunpoint is one of those "indie" games that proves there is something new under the sun. Platformer is nothing new... Donkey Kong and Mario had been around forever. Stealth games are nothing new either. Metal Gear had been around for a long time too. But combine the two, and a healthy dose of puzzle via the Crosslink, where you hack switches, doors, and more, by rewiring them to do something else, and you have something unique yet familiar. As a super freelance agent, jump, sneak, and bash your way through the levels doing work... for whatever side you choose. Graphics are pixely, but that's part of the charm. Definitely give it a try, then design your own levels with the editor and share it with the community.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												There are just not enough detective/sluth games out there. Not enough games make you feel like that underground vigilante, trying to manipulate the intrigue between competeting factions. Even less games allow you to be a clever spy tinkering with your electronic environment to outsmart guards and enemy spies. It's hard to fine that "Yes!" feeling when an intricate plan goes perfectly according to plan, leaving no witness and no casualties. There's just a certain smug satisfaction you get from watching guard try to turn a light back on, only to be opening doors or turning other lights off elsewhere. It's a certain satisfaction you can only really get out of Gunpoint right now.I'll make this somewhat brief. You should buy Gunpoint. It's an incredibly clever and fun game with lots of funny and well written dialog along with fantastic stealth gameplay. There are multiple-ish ways around each level depending on what upgrades you've gone for, and there are multiple storylines you can follow, although they don't ultimately effect the final ending. It is an incredibly polished and thought-out game, and you should play it.Although, you might want to wait for a sale. If there is a problem with Gunpoint, it's that it's way, way to short. Took only a little more than two hours to beat, and while there is some incentive to replay levels for a better rating or follow different contracts, there isn't much incentive to spend that much time with the game after beating it. There is a workshop, but it's fairly limited. There are a few good maps, but a lot of them are just boring or broken, and there's rarely something new uploaded. So, if you're the type that needs to maximize bang for your buck, $10 for 2 hours of gameplay might be too steep a price, and you might want to wait for the sale.But at some point, you should buy and play this game. Simply put, it's fantastic.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Gunpoint has come to be one of my favorite titles. Superb game with a perfect mix of stealth, strategy, action and puzzle, all seasoned with a dose of witty humor that is just as enjoyable as its clever, easy to learn gameplay. There are multiple ways to beat the levels, giving the (unfortunately) short game a good replay value; You can also play custom missions as well as create your own. And the soundtrack is just wonderful.In short: Gunpoint is a great game created with a lot of heart that should appeal to a lot of gamers due to it touching several genres without getting stuck in any of them. I found the game on sale, but I would without a doubt have payed the original 7€ for it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Gunpoint is a very unique little game. Let's get my opinions out of the way first: OMG BUY THIS GAME AND THROW MONEY AT THESE DEVELOPERS THEY ARE AMAZING.Anyways, lets get to it.Gunpoint is a great game, with a good story and great mechanics. Plus a good sense of humor.Mechanics:Its a 2d "sidescroller" platformer. Sidescroller in a loose sense of the word. In this game, you play the role of Freelance spy Richard Conway, who owns a Pair of hypertrousers, which allow him to jump great heights. after the first mission, you unlock the "Wiretapper." Which is where this game really shines, and what turns it into a puzzle game. With the wiretapper, You can change the Circuity of the building. Altering the circuits of alarms, security cameras, doors, lights, and plug sockets. The combination of these two mechanics is what makes this a great stealth game.Story: After purchasing his Hypertrousers, Conway accidentally leaps out the window of his apartment building and into the lobby of a nearby building, one in which someone was murdered. After hearing gunshots, and going up the building to investigate, conway walks in front of a security camera, which would put him at the scene of the crime, he has to erase the backups before the tapes are found.I Don't want to spoil anything, because this is all adressed by the first mission.Extras:If there isn't enough reason to buy this game, it also comes with a Level Editor, so you can make your own puzzles. And i really do hope at some point this gets steam workshop support. I'd really like to see what others come up with.Not to mention you get a free Tf2 hat with the deal. I mean, C'mon, the hat looks pretty cool.And you can have the spy wear it. Because why not.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I really like Gunpoint. There's only one or two things I dislike:1. The replay value is slightly reduced because if you replay a level and you do slightly worse, (e.g. not getting as many achievements) the game takes this to be your final score and applies it on the menu. 2. There isn't a lot of it! The main story was wonderfully witty and cleverly created, and I know there's the Workshop and level creator, but a bigger core game would have made it more perfect.The rest of it is fantastic. The movement mechanic somehow combines action and fast playing with strategy and planning in the cross-link and those brilliant hyper-trouser things. Conway's character is a hilarious parody of itself and the player. His interaction with the other characters is always funny, and I love the method of communication between them too. The art is great, I'm a sucker for pixels!Please get it, and also give the talented people on the workshop some love.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Gunpoint has come to be one of my favorite titles. Superb game with a perfect mix of stealth, strategy, action and puzzle, all seasoned with a dose of witty humor that is just as enjoyable as its clever, easy to learn gameplay. There are multiple ways to beat the levels, giving the (unfortunately) short game a good replay value; You can also play custom missions as well as create your own. And the soundtrack is just wonderful.In short: Gunpoint is a great game created with a lot of heart that should appeal to a lot of gamers due to it touching several genres without getting stuck in any of them. I found the game on sale, but I would without a doubt have payed the original 7€ for it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												There are just not enough detective/sluth games out there. Not enough games make you feel like that underground vigilante, trying to manipulate the intrigue between competeting factions. Even less games allow you to be a clever spy tinkering with your electronic environment to outsmart guards and enemy spies. It's hard to fine that "Yes!" feeling when an intricate plan goes perfectly according to plan, leaving no witness and no casualties. There's just a certain smug satisfaction you get from watching guard try to turn a light back on, only to be opening doors or turning other lights off elsewhere. It's a certain satisfaction you can only really get out of Gunpoint right now.I'll make this somewhat brief. You should buy Gunpoint. It's an incredibly clever and fun game with lots of funny and well written dialog along with fantastic stealth gameplay. There are multiple-ish ways around each level depending on what upgrades you've gone for, and there are multiple storylines you can follow, although they don't ultimately effect the final ending. It is an incredibly polished and thought-out game, and you should play it.Although, you might want to wait for a sale. If there is a problem with Gunpoint, it's that it's way, way to short. Took only a little more than two hours to beat, and while there is some incentive to replay levels for a better rating or follow different contracts, there isn't much incentive to spend that much time with the game after beating it. There is a workshop, but it's fairly limited. There are a few good maps, but a lot of them are just boring or broken, and there's rarely something new uploaded. So, if you're the type that needs to maximize bang for your buck, $10 for 2 hours of gameplay might be too steep a price, and you might want to wait for the sale.But at some point, you should buy and play this game. Simply put, it's fantastic.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Gunpoint is a very fun and extremely unique stealth-action game. Think Mark of the Ninja crossed with Watch Dogs. (I can't really explain the gameplay well, watch a trailer or something.) As soon as I saw the press demo years ago, I knew this would probably become one of my favorite games. I even bought it on its launch day. Lo and behold, I wasn't wrong. Honestly, I regret taking this long to finish it. Intriguing story, fun gameplay, neat asthetics; what more can you ask for in a game made by one guy? A bit short, but not unpleasantly so, with my playtime clocking in around 3 hours. The length feels right for the game. Even then, there's tons of replayability in the story, and if you're not into replaying, there's a level editor. A definite recommendation from me, even if you aren't a fan of stealth games. Honestly, you can play the game in so many different ways I struggle to shoehorn it into one genre like that. Definitely worth more than $10, buy it if you can.

Posted: April 22, 2016
												This game is surprisingly great. I bought it on a sale expecting a few hours of a reasonably fun game, but I got way more out of it (although not in hours, since the game is very short).All the levels are very well designed, and offer a kind of difficulty mode integrated into them - you can just fulfill your goal in any way you like, which is not that hard, or you can go to the optional objectives and requirements, which requires more of the player. It's very fun and rewarding to use all your gadgets to successfully complete an infiltration.The story is simple, but very well-told, with funny writing combined with a noir atmosphere, and a satisfiyng conclusion, which is always a plus.So, yeah, I recommend it even at full-price, even with its short length. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												In this excellent stealth-puzzler, you play a dude (a some kind of a freelance spy-detective) who just bought hypertrousers. Unfortunately, he got caught on a camera and is now a murder suspect: on to destroy the evidence because who would believe you anyway? Murderer too used the awesometrousers.Your guy can jump very high, cling to ceilings and floor and with some additional gadgets rewire the electronics systems of buildings. He does not choose his targets: his clients do. Smartpants, he accepts any mission that pays money and tries to sound witty doing that. In case it left you wondering, that pun was totally intended.A typical level goes like this: break into a building, hack into a computer and get out, and if you're like me, do it totally undetected and without hurting, let alone killing anyone. The rewind system ensures you don't have to restart too often. Actually, the ability to rewire electronics is even more important than bouncing like a cat and you may even debate whichever is the best.Definitely worth it for the sneaky-puzzly mechanics if not for the witty albeit quirky dialogue and story.

content:
Posted: January 16
												10/10 would push man through window againIt's a great game, albeit a short and buggy game, with interesting mechanics and in my opinion, great music.Pros:You can knock people out by opening a door in their faceLater in the game, the puzzles become a lot more complicatedFiguring out a stage is rewarding in its own rightYou can jump into a person, knock them out a window, drop 2 stories and turn them into a pile of bloodTons of different ways to incapacitate (or murder) peopleGreat jazzy, spy musicCons:Short. Like, really short. Shorter than the shortest person on Earth.Pretty buggy. You can push people straight through doors, and occasionally the background of buildings cease to existYou can hold someone at gunpoint, but it isn't a good idea, because bullets don't restock and they'll shoot you if you get too close.Great game, you should buy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28
												Gunpoint was an enjoyable experience and rather satisfying considering its rather short length. The gameplay is fluid, only if you the player are skilled. I am not skilled so there was a lot of floundering around however when I was playing the game well, utilising all the tools at my disposal I realised just how much depth the games mechanics have. However for some odd reason the difficulty of the game fluctuates from sit back and spend 10 minutes strategising and formulating a plan to "really, thats it?". Arguably the last two levels were dissapointing, being relatively simple and more an example of quantity rather than puzzle quality. However the sheer amount of guards and mini puzzles in the last level allow  the mechanics to shine and we see just how hectic this game can get mechanically when pushed. The length may deter some but the game is worth it for the price. The music in this game is passable. One or two tracks stand out but nothing you will find yourself humming later on. The writing is most likely going to divide players. I took the zany approach and made my character a gun wielding psychopathic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, resulting in some of the funniest dialogue I have read in a while. However I know that this writing will come of as random for the sake of random for some. It is possible however to play a straight and narrow character with no shenanigans if desired. Overall Gunpoint was a fun distraction, you will most likely beat this in one sitting and unless you enjoy challenging yourself replaying levels for times then the replayability isnt really there. There are some alternate dialogues depending on the ingame choices but not much besides that. But the pixel art style, dialogue, story and combat makes this a worthwile indie title to play on a lazy day. I give gunpoint a 2.5 out of 5.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
												Game is great, but also buggyGameplay: its a puzzle platformer with stealth elements.Bad stuff:- Game wont minimize properly, even when it runs in windowed mode, it just wants to be on top (alt tab + random clicking did the trick once)- Game looks zoomed in/out on different resolutions. which is weird... 1080p too small (but i played it like that) 800x640 you can only see a small part of the map, it limits you on small resolutions.- Undo feature (to make you go back is useful ) but its weird at the same time, it just returns you sometimes in weird places/random times, one time 0 seconds, other times 60+secondsMeh: - Tools, i think developers were thinking, lets add more stuff just to add content, and lets add this gadget, and that gadget... most of the stuff is not even needed. you can finish the entire game just by using the jumping and rewire tool (even the last level, i successfully finished it without the door breaking thing, that the game said it was required). i used some tools just to get the achievement. ( I WOULD USE THEM MORE IF I HAD MANY BATTERIES TO USE THEM ) - Enemies, there are only 3 types of enemies, normal guard, tough guard, and elite guard. i would prefer if there were more enemies, with different abilities.- Maps, most of them are ok, but the only thing that challenged me for a few minutes was the last one map middle part puzzle (because of the resolution it took me a while to see what is going where) the rest are mostly simple. i would add some traps, for example if you make a mistake that the game locks you in a room (That happend only once to me on the last map)Good stuff:- The gameplay is good, you can go full stealth ninja ghost :) or full psycho.- Story is ok- It has some humor- Workshop (level editor)

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												GUNPOINT IS A TREASURE. I can't possibly recommend it enough.The creative gameplay mechanic of "rewiring" elements of the level mean that there's a lot of flexibility in playstyle and even in solutions to each mission. Use your sneaky spy tools to switch off lights, avoid cameras, and disable traps--or enable them right as a guard walks past. Or just shoot everyone in the face. Or do a combination of both. It's the greatest.The dialogue is awesome too: funny, perfectly interactive, and seasoned with a dash of noir-detective smarm.The main campaign is short--it took me, the world's slowest gamer, about 5 hours, so it should take most normal folks about half that time--but it has full Steam Workshop support with a level editor for player-creatable maps, and I played it again to get better stealth ratings on some of the missions and still loved it the second time around.Art style may not be to everyone's taste (I loved it, personally) but I think the fun of the gameplay is well worth giving this game a shot even if you're hesitant about it.Rating: 5/55: Loved it; 4: Liked it; 3: It's OK; 2: Didn't like it; 1: Hated it

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												An incredibly simple premise with astounding execution. The story centers around a freelance spy named Conway that was almost framed for the murder of a friend and employee of a weapons manufacturing company, basing itself on the whole "Cyberpunk future" idea and possibilities. For instance, Conway owns a pair of high-tech pants that allow him to jump to ludicrous heights and sustain little to no falling damage, as well as a device that allows him to rewire virtually anything connected to a power source to fulfill whatever needs he might have. And let's not forget corrupt companies with their evil tycoons sitting at the CEO chair.Graphically speaking, it's hit-and-miss. If you like pixel art, you'll like this game's style, but if you don't, well, at least the gameplay and music can make it up to you.Musically speaking, spectacular. If you're a fan of old noir movies and games, the atmospheric soundtrack to this game will touch your inner detective.And finally, gameplay. 2D sidescrolling with high jumping and stealth elements, in a nutshell. Every thing is responsive, you definitely feel in control of your environment as Conway peruses the electrical grid of the building he's trying to sneak into and of Conway himself, as he either skillfully jumps into an open window, pummels someone to a temporary coma (or death) or silently crawls on ceilings and walls avoiding the watchful eyes of the guards.All in all, this game is fantastic. Props to Tom Francis and his development team.

												Game is great, but also buggyGameplay: its a puzzle platformer with stealth elements.Bad stuff:- Game wont minimize properly, even when it runs in windowed mode, it just wants to be on top (alt tab + random clicking did the trick once)- Game looks zoomed in/out on different resolutions. which is weird... 1080p too small (but i played it like that) 800x640 you can only see a small part of the map, it limits you on small resolutions.- Undo feature (to make you go back is useful ) but its weird at the same time, it just returns you sometimes in weird places/random times, one time 0 seconds, other times 60+secondsMeh: - Tools, i think developers were thinking, lets add more stuff just to add content, and lets add this gadget, and that gadget... most of the stuff is not even needed. you can finish the entire game just by using the jumping and rewire tool (even the last level, i successfully finished it without the door breaking thing, that the game said it was required). i used some tools just to get the achievement. ( I WOULD USE THEM MORE IF I HAD MANY BATTERIES TO USE THEM ) - Enemies, there are only 3 types of enemies, normal guard, tough guard, and elite guard. i would prefer if there were more enemies, with different abilities.- Maps, most of them are ok, but the only thing that challenged me for a few minutes was the last one map middle part puzzle (because of the resolution it took me a while to see what is going where) the rest are mostly simple. i would add some traps, for example if you make a mistake that the game locks you in a room (That happend only once to me on the last map)Good stuff:- The gameplay is good, you can go full stealth ninja ghost :) or full psycho.- Story is ok- It has some humor- Workshop (level editor)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												The game presents you with a simple objective (hack this, steal that) each level but gives you a really useful set of tricks to accomplish your goal.  The way this is presented and your control of the game world is what makes this title stand out.  I've managed to wire a light switch to an elevator call button, which sets of a sound alarm which opens a door granting me access to a locked room for example. The game has various electronic devices (buttons, lights, elevators, alarms, doors, cameras) that are nominally assigned to coloured circuits.  You can wire devices up in a building any way you like as long as you don't cross coloured circuits, however judicious use of the aforementioned sound detectors etc. will let you do this.  Play it, makes me think a bit of the cancelled Introversion game 'Subversion'.  I'm not going to mention any of the plot, it's good and serves it's purpose quite well with charm and style. I really quite like this, the main 'campaign' is short (about 3 or so hours if you fiddle about) but quite wonderfully done.  The levels are very well designed with absolutely loads of routes and tactics that can be taken to beat them.  You really can go back and play each level an entirely different way.  The level designer as it stands I've found easier than most to use, however it seems to be less capabable than the ones used to create the in game levels.  I cannot seem to wire places up to the same degree, and I cannot find any way to access the sound sensors etc. present in the main campaign.  My understanding though is the levels and campaign are straight forward text files so editing/creating anything used in the main campaign is well within reach.So yes, buy it on the understanding that the included content is quite short but well worth the money and you'll have a minor amount of legwork to do for extra levels (try http://www.gunpointlevels.net/).An advanced level editor is also available here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/206190/discussions/0/864971139146390709/

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												PLEASE BUY THIS GAMEDo yourself a huge favor and check it out. And line the pockets of some really slick developers. They deserve it. How is it that I am more satisfied with this $10 game ($3, if you get it during this sale), than with the $60 Watch_Dogs. One of the few games that actually delivers on the "Solve The Puzzle Your Way" claims. It plays very smoothly. Very responsive. And it's free-form in a lot of ways. The mechanics of the game are sound, and extremely satisfying. The writing and dialogue is phenomenal. I laughed SO hard at some of the dialogue choices.Don't even get me started on the soundtrack. It's such a perfect feel for the game. It really makes you feel like a sly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sometimes. Other times you feel like a total buffoon, and you get shot in the♥♥♥♥♥ which is equally as entertaining. And all the little things they added. All the nuiance. The little things are what make it. It's like Casablanca and Shadowrun got together and made a (hilarious) baby.I liked it as a whole package. Nothing, not a thing about it was disappointing, and it even exceeded my expectations frequently. And in case you're worried about replayability? Level editor. After playing it, I had to go back and download the special edition DLC that comes with the soundtrack. That's pretty rare for me.Full points. Also, the people who are saying that this game is too short, and unsatisfying after one run-through, don't know how to make their own fun. I'm personally going to do at least two, considering there are so many different ways a situation can play out. Don't knock points off the game because you aren't creative enough to get your enjoyment out of it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Gunpoint is a film noir-inspired puzzle game by indie developer Tom Francis. The game consists of a variety of puzzles that are solved using your crosslink, a handy hacking device that you use to rewire doors, buttons and other assorted mechanisms. These puzzles are weaved together by an excellent story. You play as Richard Conway, a detective who is out to clear his name after being framed for murder. The music in this game is phenomenal. The soundtrack consists of many jazz tracks, most of which are remixed in a more techno-esque fashion. I 100% completed the game in 7.4 hours, including all achievements and A+'s in all the levels. The final level of the game is one of the best in any game ever, providing an extremely satisfying ending. My only complaint is that the game is a tad short, but this could be easily solved by a story-expanding DLC release.OVERALL RATING: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												Gunpoint is a fun little game. I cannot compare it to anything I've played before, but it could be described as stealth puzzle game. Mostly it's about connecting devices to other to make them work properly so the protagonist can continue his investigation. Combinations are sometimes fun, but options felt lacking; or my imagination was. I just felt that there could've been more "to do", but I guess that there would've if I've tried to do A+ in everything. Jumping guards was too easy that made the game less about stealth and more about wiring and jumping.Music is nice and graphics are okay. Visually the game looks clear but somewhat boring. Then again it works so smooth, it doesn't really matter. The plot kept me interested in the game so I pretty much played this game in one day. The game lasted for about 4 hours for me and that was pretty much enough. It didn't get repetetive nor boring at any point. One can try to improve their stats afterwards, but apart from that, the game is pretty much done.It's hard to recommend this kind of game because I lack reference points. If you try the complete version, you almost surely will complete it before you made up your mind about playing it any further. There's a demo though, so if you didn't get this from a bundle, try the demo before bying.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Gunpoint isn't the hardest of action puzzle-games, but it is certainly one of the very best.There's a certain kind of  humour running through the entire game, the game looks great visually, it has a coherent art style (the music, theme and graphics all fit together) and the puzzles are interesting - often giving an out-of-box feeling when you manage to solve them in that perfect way.In short: it is very polished and great at what it is trying to be. Just get it.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												A very refreshing take on platforming games, injecting a healthy dose of stealth and tacticts into the jumping and running. (Does anyone remember Impossible Mission on the C64? Not that this would be similar - just asking..)You jump, run and climb your way through office buldings, avoiding guards and re-wiring electrical and electronic circuits such as lights, security cameras and elevator bells to help you get through each level. The dialogue in between missions is hilarious.Even the gameplay has humour in it.I really recommend this game. And while you'll have it finished in about five hours, there are tons of user levels available. No campaigns however, just individual levels.

												Do you love being a badass without getting out of your house? Sure you do, you have Steam. Gunpoint is a beautiful little 2D puzzle-platformer game, in which you play as a freelancing agent. The levels are very well put toghether, and are not too difficult, if you think hard enough. +Old fashioned-esque beauitiful graphics+Makes you feel like a baddass-WARNING: Contains adult language and violence=Crude humor, I love it, some might not.=Short story, made up for in decent replayability, especcially with the post-game powerups.10/10, No complaints. content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Picked this up in a sale for next-to-nothing.  Fun game, albeit terribly short - under 6 hours to complete at a leisurely pace.Gunpoint shows that super-duper graphics is not required to make fun game-play.  It's a fairly simple puzzle game, and nothing is going to leave you thinking for long.  The challenge comes in your style.  Trying to complete a level without being seen etc.  Getting to the objective quickly and out is fairly simple but not very rewarding.Don't pay full price for this game, but if you see it in a bargain bin then pick it up.  I played it on my laptop with my feet up - it's that sort of game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Wow, where to begin...I bought this on the Steam Christmas Sale 2014 as something to play on my awful laptop. I should perhaps mention that I had no idea what the game was about at the time, but it was cheap and scored high on Metacritic.What did I find? One of the best games I have played in recent years. It is difficult to explain just why it is so good without spoiling the game, suffice it to say that both the story and mechanics, as well as their execution, are without fault. The game has a subtle, dark sense of humour which punctuates its noir storytelling. In terms of actual gameplay, I would describe it as an immersive puzzle platformer, though its beauty is that each problem can be approached in a variety of ways.  The game is not particularly long, and I completed it in roughly four hours, though my playstyle is ponderous at best. However, that should not discourage you from spending money on this gem of a game. The variety of solutions as well as the multitude of achievements will make subsequent playthroughs as riveting as the first.In conclusion: Buy it, download it, play it, recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												Charming, funny and clever. Three words that are usually the signs of a well-made game.Whilst it's not going to keep you up at night racking your brain on how to beat that ONE level, it's enough of a challenge to keep your brain ticking over.A standard 2D stealth-em-up with a novel twist, the game encourages and rewards creativity, although if you get frustrated, there's always the option to go charging in as well. The dialogue between missions bounces from pretty amusing to out-and-out hilarious without ever compromising a story that becomes more interesting and less 'token' than you may think at first glance.Personally, this is well worth your money if you have even a passing interest in this sort of game. A very pleasant impulse buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Just had a very agreeable day with Gunpoint. The plot is an entertaining and irreverent take on the noir and robot trouser genres. If you fancy some indie fun that features: progressively intricate levels, puzzling, stealthing about, leaping with a callus disregard for gravity, and (when the time is right) kicking bloody doors in. Then this is the game for you. The gameplay is well balanced you feel badass, but extremely vulnerable at the same time.The story shows hidden depths and just like the building offers you a degree of choice about how you tackle it. Primarily how serious you want to take it. The pixel art is pitch perfect. It hits that level of representing what's being shown, rather than looking like a compressed image or generic block figures. However pixel art does make it harder to judge if a character is supposed to be a classic femme fatal.I'm looking forward to an expansion pack or whatever comes next from this developer. In the mean there's a level editor and a growing list of maps in the steam workshop. Few really stand out yet but I'm sure it's just a matter of time.

												The hacking in this game is better than Watch Dogs. Yes, I am being serious.Gunpoint is a new unique indie game that is very fun and worth $10. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Gunpoint, on the surface is puzzle platformer with quirky dialog. Deep down; however, Gunpoint offers humour, a good twisty narative, and fresh take on the murder mystery genre. The plot itself is relatively similar to other hard-boiled detective stories thyat provide a corrupt corporate executive and the girl who's caught up in it all (ie, Ian Rankin's 'Let it Bleed,' or Raymond Chandler's 'The Big Sleep') but this game gives you control over Conway in the dialog portions. Allowign the player to choose what style of character Conway is what really makes this game special. The player gets 3 basic choices of personality: stoic, crazy, and not-giving-a♥♥♥♥♥♥ All 3 are wonderful, and this alone would make me recommend this game, but when you add on the exceptionally fun gameplay, Gunpoint stands above many other puzzle-platformers of its ilk.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014



YouTube™ Video: SteamPunk Episode 8: Gunpoint 

			Views: 32		

			SteamPunk Bob insists that the game designer ripped off the idea for this game from his award winning fanfiction: "From the Files of Police Squad! The Maltese Batman"		

It's a stealth game, but it's so much more. It includes important information to the stealth genre, such as knowing what guards can and cannot see. You can choose how you're going to solve your issues. Will you use subtlety and grace, guards not knowing there was a break in? Do you wait until they turn their back, then tackle and beat them unconcious? Do you hunt and murder every possible witness?There's interaction between your various clients, and it's just good fun.

												The gameplay encourages creativity without punishing mistakes. Each mission gives you an objective; how you complete that objective is completely up to you. No playstyle or mechanic takes precedence over any other. With its smart design, creative mechanics and Film Noir atmosphere (complemented with an impressive soundtrack) Gunpoint is one of the best gameplay experiences I’ve had in recent years. My only complaint is that the story only takes about 2 hours to complete.The Steam achievements are a lot of fun adding to the replayability.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Gunpoint is a 2d stealth/puzzle game. You can rewire devices in the level to do certain things, such as rewiring a light switch so that instead of turning out the lights, it opens a door into a guard, knocking him out. There are a ton of devices that all do different things when triggered and you can wire almost any combination of triggers/devices together. Your character is also very mobile: you can crawl up walls and hang from the ceiling, and you can superjump with a pair of robolegs your character buys in the opening cutscene. Levels also have a couple of collectibles, in the form of laptops that you can hack to read emails from the game's characters. The characters are really well written, and the dialog is pretty funny. The characters will also give optional goals at the start of levels if you want more of a challenge. And if you want to spend more than a couple of hours on the game, you had really better go for every one of those challenges and collectibles, because this game is short as HELL. I took my time and meandered about the levels, reset them a few times, and I still beat the whole game in like 3 hours. There's a level editor with workshop integration, but a game shouldn't have to rely on user generated content to last for more than one short sitting.In short;PROS: solid gameplay with interesting mechanics, well written characters, funny dialogCONS: short as hell, can easily be beaten in a few hours

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												A simple, short game about a spy with no allegiances who's just trying to keep himself from getting screwed over and make some money. Gunpoint's strategy with a stealth element and it's game mecahnics are what really makes the game unique. They are fascinating because they make you think in terms of open and closed circuts - e.g. object A does this which triggers object B and electrocutes a guard. While it's easy to catch on, it's not so easy that mental effort isn't required - I'd say medium on the challenging scale. If just doing the bare minimum, one can finish this game in a matter of hours, but there are extra achievements possible for doing levels with a specific style or speed if that's your kind of thing. The dialogue is cute and made me laugh. While it's not an adventure game per say, you are given a few choices that will affect the game. And the ability to choose different dialogue options in between missions made me feel more invested in my character. (For example, I made my character as snarky as possible.) The music is well done and quite fitting, as is the 16-bit design; both really help to aid the cloak and dagger atmosphere for our spy protagonist. All in all it's a cute little indie game that's definitely worth getting on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												The beauty of Gunpoint is its simplicity: the visuals are low-fi, but the gameplay is decidedly high-tech. Equipped with mechanical trousers that permit you to leap tall buildings in a--well, a couple of bounds--you assume the role of a detective caught up in a murder conspiracy, armed with only your pants and a couple of upgrades. It's one of the most deliciously well-written, atmospheric, and satisfying puzzlers I've played in a long time. VISUALS: Simple and clean, pixel-art that communicates the environment without any clutter to distract you from the gameplay. SOUND/MUSIC: The tunes in this game are legitimately good listening all on their own, but they add a noir ambience that is undeniably a character unto itself. GAMEPLAY: Aside from acrobatic feats, you can use a wiremapping device to re-wire entire buildings, so that a light-switch in one room might short a light socket in another--and thereby electrocute and pacify a patrolling guard. There are many opportunities for game-breaking shenanigans here. Add in a level creator and you've got room for plenty of replayability. Great stealth-action title, very funny, highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I can only recommend this with a caveat: DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE.For some reason, there are a lot of developers out there with much hate in their heart for headphone-wearing gamers.  Gunpoint doubles the hate quotient by neglecting to include options for remapping the controls, as well as the sound volume.  You do get the option to change your (windowed) screen resolution, but it requires restarting the game.  For the $10-$15 price that Gunpoint is asking, I expect a game written in a proper framework that supports all the conventional options that have been the norm for PC gaming for decades now.  Instead, we get a game that feels like it was made using the same kind of software people use for creating training videos or websites.  It's great that there's authorware out there that enables people with creative vision to make games without requiring any technical know-how, but I don't want to see the resulting products proffered up at the same price as purpose-built software.  There are a quite a few other games in this price range that have the polish of AAA titles, but everything about Gunpoint feels amateurish.  With that out of the way, please let me say that this is a pretty fun puzzle game.  The rewiring mechanic is well executed, and sets this game apart from other 2D puzzlers and platformers.

												I'm rarely an impulse buyer when it comes to new releases.  In fact I more resemble a certain XKCD comic about delayed enjoyment of major releases.  Somethng about Gunpoint though grabbed me right off.  I threw my $9 down and let the chips fall where they may.  They... uhm... I'm not sure how to finish that metaphor.  It wasn't $9 wasted, let's just say that.The entire thing is a wonderful mix of retro-puzzle-cool, with visuals in the vein of a 386-era platformer but with that modern twist of ingenuity and "hey, you're a spy now, cool!"  The ambiance is great, very 30's hardboiled/gumshoe/spy but with a pseudo-modern setting and sci-fi gadgetry.  As a kid, did you ever wish there was an awesome "be a super spy" game that you could play?  This is that game, except designed by an adult with rather good development sensibilities.The gameplay itself is that perfect mix of "easy to pick up" and "takes practice".  All your gadgets have their obvious uses, but after you spend enough time playing around you start to learn all the other cool things they can do... and the other cool trouble they can get you into.  You can generally get through the game if you take your time, but after you do you can challenge yourself to do it faster and possibly with certain restrictions, like never knocking out a guard or even being seen by one.  Yes, you will want to play it again.Gunpoint's plot is satisfying but somewhat short, leaving you wanting more.  As I said above you can get some of that satisfaction from playing the game over again, or even going back through old levels with your new gadgetry to completely break the intended puzzle aspects.  There's also a level editor and the ability to load custom levels, which can further satisfy that need for more.  The only downside is that they can't (as far as I can tell) be arranged into a plot-based progression like the main ones are.The last thing I'll say in this surprisingly long recommendation is that the game really reminds me of Deus Ex, of all things.  That's hardly surprising though given that the game was designed by Tom Francis, a self-confessed fan of the game who's written articles on it for major game publications as recently as 2010.  Gunpoint definitely has that "multiple solutions to every problem" thing down, and it tickles that same part of my Game-brain.In short, buy this if you like Deus Ex and/or puzzle platformers and/or spy coolness.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Quite an entertaining game. If I had to summarize this game in a single sentence, I'd probably say "A game about feeling stealthy". I don't know how else to say it, I really don't. This has been the first "stealth" game I have played where I have felt truly stealthy and badass. And I've played quite a few, and found the stealth sections to be boring and annoying. The soundtrack probably brings some of those feelings. The soundtrack is fantastic, albeit short, and every track is a joy to listen to. If you want a small dose of the music, I'd recommend listening to the trailer. The storyline is lacking, but I wouldn't consider that to be something that makes it a terrible game. In fact, even without a storyline, this game still shines. The storyline does what it should do, however. It gives you an objective. A villain, per-se. And that's all you really need. Last of all, the gameplay is what brings it all together. Early in the game, you are given the ability to "jump". It's exactly what you think. You can do whatever you want with it, though. Climb on walls, hang on ceilings, etc. All the while, being extremely unrealistic and silly. The other main mechanic, the rewiring of electricity, is a joy. For any puzzle game enthusiasts, this part of the game is for you. However, don't expect any puzzles to be too complex. There are multiple ways to reach your endgoal. And all of them are fun. I would definitely recommend this game even if it is very short.8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												Gunpoint is a special game to me. It was one of the first games I bought on Steam and I can't get enough of it. Gunpoint is one of the, if not the best, indie game I have ever played.Pros:The crosslink is a really cool feature and it makes you think about where you need to wire buttons or motion/sound detectors or unwire them to prevent one of the AI from activating what you just activated.The story is pretty cool. It isn't the best story I've ever seen but it's good in it's own right and I was interested the entire way through the game to know what would eventually happen. SPOILER: The ending is really cool to me, I like that you find the killer and finally face up against him and Fritz and avenge Selena's death.The soundtrack is awesome and it sounds appropriate for this game. This easily passes for me because I'm a sucker for good music.The game is an overall fun experience. It's definetly one that I'll never forget.The art in Gunpoint looks nice. The backgrounds are really detailed and the levels have so much detail to them, too. The game never gets too hard to the point where you want to punch a hole into a wall. The game is well-balanced.The outlets.Cons:There isn't really a bonus at the end of the game for getting all of the achievements and getting A+ on every level.In the end, Gunpoint is a really amazing game. I wasn't expecting much going into Gunpoint as I only bought it for $5 while on a sale. I was very surprised at first when I completed Gunpoint and ended up loving it. I always come back to the game when I'm bored to get lower times on levels I had a couple minutes on. It's really cool to complete your record you got from the beginning of the game in more than half the time... and it feels great to beat a level faster than the developer.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Short: Buy it when it is on sale. Great game. Funny. Very short. Little replay value after finishing story.Not too long of a game. Didn't take too long to progress through the game. It has some pretty funny dialogue, some good puzzle solving, fitting graphics, immersive music soundtrack, and quite a bit of unexpected satisfaction after face punching an agent in the face over 250+ times while simultaneously earning an achievement for it that I had no clue about. That, in my opinion, made up for the time it took to get through the game (taking my sweet time). Launched an armored guard out of a 6 story window. Kicked several doors down in a few guards' faces. Had some good fun. Bought it during the Autumn sale for less than 1/3 the price. Don't regret it at all. Well worth the price that I got it for on sale.If you haven't checked out this game, give it a shot. However, if it isn't on sale, I would definitely wait. The normal price is a no go since it is a bit short and has only a little bit of replay value.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												This is an excellent game.Main premise: You are an industrial spy who wears a cool hat and a trenchcoat while trying to solve a murder (and make a killing in the meantime). You have two main abilities to help you do this (besides the hat): the BullFrog Jump Trousers which allow you to jump absurdly high distances and your Crosslink which allows you to hack into nearly any system, influding doors, security cameras, guns, trapdoors, and so on. The game requires you to master both of these abilities to be able to complete the brilliant puzzles it throws at you.In case you didn't know this already, this is a puzzle game. The main point of the game is to solve puzzles by avoiding (or slaying) guards and hacking systems to acheive some objective.Another fun element of the game is how much control you have over your character's morality. I personally tried to play the game without killing, hitting, or being seen by any guards, a feat I did not successfully accomplish. You can just as legitimately try to tackle every guard out of a window, however. There isn't that much of a different ending either way, but it was fun to try and solve the puzzles in so many different ways.All in all, Gunpoint is a great puzzle game that I really enjoyed. My only critique is a relatively small one: the bug causing the game to crash on my computer unless I disable the Steam Overlay is a little irritating, especially because it keeps me from being able to play the Steam Workshop levels. Overall a great game, however. Keep 'em coming!

content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												A short game, but its worth every single second. The breaking of the forth wall and well developed, funny, interesting dialog made it worth punching a dude 300 times in the face. Plus the puzzling twists and multiple ending / choices even early in the game made it feel new.Plus the creativity of the maps was brilliant, making you think with all of your wit. The realism and realistic AI is shown when you break glass, a guard rushes out of its designated area to investigate, then the AI sets them there. Finally, the open ended was to beat each level makes me play a level 5 times, just to see if I find a new responce. The game to me felt like a glued paper, you would need a crowbar to get me off.I dont know. . .I feel like this game, it grows on your personality, considering I am the main character.But if you love punching a guy in the face, crosslinking doors to hit a guy in the face on the push of a button, kicking doors, doing whatever the f*ck you want since your freelance, this is your game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Words that describe Gunpoint and my time while playing: Fun, Exciting, Plentiful, Achievements ♥♥♥♥♥, Frustrating, Puzzling, Mysterious, etc.My first indie game that I played and bought on steam happened to be Gunpoint. Ever since I got the game, I have had countless hours of enjoyable fun with over 4 playthroughs already to my profile and also a steam community workshop item. Ever since I bought the game, I have been able to watch it grow and prosper through the new updates along with the new community fanbase, something that is easily visible through the steam workshop titles, and also the third party programs that people have used in partnership with the developers to design custom levels with textures other than from in the regular editor. My personal opinion of the game coming into it was that of excitement and joy, because of how the game was a perfect match to my playing style and how it was easy enough to get achievements (which I love). It provided me with a 4 hour straight period of joy and commitment that led to me wanting more out of the game and also the game's level editor. I felt the need after everything, to show my experience with the world and essentially show how much fun the game was. Overall however, the game's graphics are smooth and artful, providing a meaningful experience even on "toasters" that will never fail to provide you with continous fun throughout your day. If I had to give this game a score, I would most definently give it a 10/10 no matter what people have to say about it.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												For those who want a quick answer: INCREDIBLE. BUY. IT. NOW.For those who want to know why:This is game is exactly what I expected Watch Dogs to be like - either using clever tricks to outsmart your enemies and stealth to try to avoid violence, or running in and rushing the objective, not caring about what, or who, gets in you way. However, in every conceivable way, this game is far, far, far better than Watch Dogs. SO, are you considering buying Watch Dogs? Don't. Buy 5 copies of this instead. The mechanics are impeccable, the intriguing story keeps you playing until the end, then lets you replay any mission you want - with your new upgrades. I can honestly say, this is one of the best games I have ever played, and the best £6 I have ever spent.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Gunpoint, on the surface is puzzle platformer with quirky dialog. Deep down; however, Gunpoint offers humour, a good twisty narative, and fresh take on the murder mystery genre. The plot itself is relatively similar to other hard-boiled detective stories thyat provide a corrupt corporate executive and the girl who's caught up in it all (ie, Ian Rankin's 'Let it Bleed,' or Raymond Chandler's 'The Big Sleep') but this game gives you control over Conway in the dialog portions. Allowign the player to choose what style of character Conway is what really makes this game special. The player gets 3 basic choices of personality: stoic, crazy, and not-giving-a♥♥♥♥♥♥ All 3 are wonderful, and this alone would make me recommend this game, but when you add on the exceptionally fun gameplay, Gunpoint stands above many other puzzle-platformers of its ilk.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2013
												This is easily one of the best downloadable "indie" games I've ever played. Incredibly simple in its mechanics, it still manages to deliver a suprising amount of depth due to the way it lets the player get through the missions in any way they see fit. The simple gameplay feels very satisfying, the puzzles are clever, and the noir soundtrack and 8/16 bit era look of the game are pitch perfect. This is just overall great, no-frills gameplay stripped down to its purest form. I really, really hope that Tom Francis (the developer) gives us more of this, whether it be DLC, an expansion, or a sequel, because this was one of the most enjoyable games I've had the pleasure of playing in quite some time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Wow, where to begin...I bought this on the Steam Christmas Sale 2014 as something to play on my awful laptop. I should perhaps mention that I had no idea what the game was about at the time, but it was cheap and scored high on Metacritic.What did I find? One of the best games I have played in recent years. It is difficult to explain just why it is so good without spoiling the game, suffice it to say that both the story and mechanics, as well as their execution, are without fault. The game has a subtle, dark sense of humour which punctuates its noir storytelling. In terms of actual gameplay, I would describe it as an immersive puzzle platformer, though its beauty is that each problem can be approached in a variety of ways.  The game is not particularly long, and I completed it in roughly four hours, though my playstyle is ponderous at best. However, that should not discourage you from spending money on this gem of a game. The variety of solutions as well as the multitude of achievements will make subsequent playthroughs as riveting as the first.In conclusion: Buy it, download it, play it, recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Gunpoint is an awesome puzzle/strategy game that is available on all platforms. The game is short (less than four hours) but because the in-game level editor could potentially provide a lot more play time, I would say this game is definitely worth it. The gameplay is new and excellent.Pros:+Excellent and unique gameplay+Cheesy but funny humor+Great noir feel to the game (with the exception of the goofy jokes, but they're funny, so it's ok)+Level editor for making and sharing your own levelsCons:-Main game is very short (took like 3.5 hours for me)-Game menus sometimes feel a little unpolished; not sure how to describe it, they just feel slightly unfinished in some way. However, this does not make the menus difficult to navigate and is not present during the actual gameplay.-(Linux only) Did not work in XFCE for some reason. I switched to dwm and the game worked.The real reason to buy Gunpoint is that the gameplay is new and innovative. It's also the kind of game where the amount of crazy scenarios that can occur can go way beyond the main game, which is why the level editor is such a great feature. I recommend it at full price, particularly if you love noir or puzzles. If it's on sale it's a no-brainer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
												If you enjoy games such as Deadbolt and Mark of the Ninja where basic stealth mechanics are blended with puzzle ones, you will almost certainly enjoy Gunpoint, an indie game that I picked up on sale last year for £1.50. If you are a fan of games with stealth mechanics that are fleshed out further like Dishonoured and the Deus Ex games, you be tempted to give Gunpoint a miss, but there are still plenty of mechanics despite this that make Gunpoint an overall brilliant game for fans of puzzle and stealth games alike.It's main mechanic, "crosslinking" means that your character is able to rewire objects by hacking them. This mechanic means that there are several ways to clear missions. For example, if there is a locked door in your way, you could simply rewire the light switch next to you to open the door, or you could be slightly more creative by turning off the lights to bait a guard into pressing the light switch, then rewiring the light switch to the door to open it. This mechanic is very satisfying as most of the time, I found myself finding strategies just by experimenting with the rewiring mechanic. This is also helped by there being no intrusive and mundane tutorial sections. Instead you have the choice to be guided through a short and basic tutorial for a specific item. The rest is left up to you.Pros:-The art style (pixel graphics) are similar to those shown in games like Hyper Light Drifter and Papers Please, and is a very beautiful and minimalistic depiction of a cyberpunk style city.-The upgrade system, while being very basic is also very rewarding. Without spoiling much, many gadgets that make your missions easier and more satisfying can be purchased. Some examples include the ability to hack plug sockets so you can electrocute guards who walk past them, the ability to jump through windows without making any sound and the ability to hack enemy guns. You would think that with the eventual progression of upgrades, the missions would become easier, but many of your gadgets drain the charge on your battery meter meaning that the strategic use of these gadgets is better than running in and using all of them.-You can complete most levels with your basic equipment (although some later missions require specific items) although they are much harder this way. This means that specific missions are rarely tied to one specific mechanic and there are many ways to carry out your mission as I mentioned before.-Although the game can be completed in around 3 hours, I believe that the starting price of the game (around £6.99) is worth it since the game is extremely replayable. I have played through the game twice in the last 6 months and plan to again soon. The missions can be replayed to get a better score in aspects such as the amount of noise you make, if you were seen during your mission or not and whether you killed guards or knocked them out. Furthermore, there is a level editor that functions really well, meaning that after you have played through the main story, you can play and create levels in the Steam Workshop.-For people who don't really care about this stuff, then ignore this. The soundtrack to Gunpoint is one of my favourites of all time. It is a perfect blend of electro music and jazz and I sometimes listen to it to relax. Because the sound effects in each level are limited, the music is not background music, but rather part of the level itself. -As for the story, it's not Mass Effect but there are a few choices in dialogue that will change the outcome of the story. Most exchanges are done through text conversations and you have the choice to respond to characters seriously or jokingly, often with fourth-wall breaking lines. Although these exchanges mostly do not affect the story, the dialogue is well written and witty.-Speaking of funny things, the achievements in this game are actual achievements you have to go out of your way to complete. In the first playthrough of the game, you will likely only get a few, but they are very creative ones. One example of this is if you kick down a door and knocka guard over, you are rewarded with an achievement appropriately called "Open Door Policy".-The story is simple, yet satisfying. The plot uses many standard spy film tropes but manages to hold up because of the witty protagonist and the interesting cast of characters you are speaking to.Cons:-The autosave feature, where when you die, lets you continue from a choice of three points in your mission, some recently and some a few minutes ago. Becuase there is no icon or autosave animation, you sometimes do not know where you will respawn.-The atosave feature also sometimes decides to save right when a guard would spot you if you were not paying attention, so when you reload it, you instantly die.-I encountered probelms in my playthrough where I would clip through walls when I jumped at them, meaning I had to restart the mission again. Although this only happened twice, it was very annoying to have to restart becuase of a glitch I had no control over.-Becuase the story is presented through text, you have to be paying attention to follow the story. Normally this is fine as you are only reading short messages, but sometimes you are faced with a large chunk of text to read. This meant that the story was more convoluted than I would have hoped.Overall, Gunpoint does very well at blending puzzle and stealth gameplay into a strategic and methodical game. The writing is hilarious and the pixel art visuals look great. Only a few technical problems and bugs stop this game from being perfect.Gunpoint gets a 9/10

To your help, you're given a device that can help you hack the environment around you; everything from doors to power sockets. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												I'm rarely an impulse buyer when it comes to new releases.  In fact I more resemble a certain XKCD comic about delayed enjoyment of major releases.  Somethng about Gunpoint though grabbed me right off.  I threw my $9 down and let the chips fall where they may.  They... uhm... I'm not sure how to finish that metaphor.  It wasn't $9 wasted, let's just say that.The entire thing is a wonderful mix of retro-puzzle-cool, with visuals in the vein of a 386-era platformer but with that modern twist of ingenuity and "hey, you're a spy now, cool!"  The ambiance is great, very 30's hardboiled/gumshoe/spy but with a pseudo-modern setting and sci-fi gadgetry.  As a kid, did you ever wish there was an awesome "be a super spy" game that you could play?  This is that game, except designed by an adult with rather good development sensibilities.The gameplay itself is that perfect mix of "easy to pick up" and "takes practice".  All your gadgets have their obvious uses, but after you spend enough time playing around you start to learn all the other cool things they can do... and the other cool trouble they can get you into.  You can generally get through the game if you take your time, but after you do you can challenge yourself to do it faster and possibly with certain restrictions, like never knocking out a guard or even being seen by one.  Yes, you will want to play it again.Gunpoint's plot is satisfying but somewhat short, leaving you wanting more.  As I said above you can get some of that satisfaction from playing the game over again, or even going back through old levels with your new gadgetry to completely break the intended puzzle aspects.  There's also a level editor and the ability to load custom levels, which can further satisfy that need for more.  The only downside is that they can't (as far as I can tell) be arranged into a plot-based progression like the main ones are.The last thing I'll say in this surprisingly long recommendation is that the game really reminds me of Deus Ex, of all things.  That's hardly surprising though given that the game was designed by Tom Francis, a self-confessed fan of the game who's written articles on it for major game publications as recently as 2010.  Gunpoint definitely has that "multiple solutions to every problem" thing down, and it tickles that same part of my Game-brain.In short, buy this if you like Deus Ex and/or puzzle platformers and/or spy coolness.

												This is easily one of the best downloadable "indie" games I've ever played. Incredibly simple in its mechanics, it still manages to deliver a suprising amount of depth due to the way it lets the player get through the missions in any way they see fit. The simple gameplay feels very satisfying, the puzzles are clever, and the noir soundtrack and 8/16 bit era look of the game are pitch perfect. This is just overall great, no-frills gameplay stripped down to its purest form. I really, really hope that Tom Francis (the developer) gives us more of this, whether it be DLC, an expansion, or a sequel, because this was one of the most enjoyable games I've had the pleasure of playing in quite some time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Now let's have a look at the pros and cons of the story line first.(I know that you urge for them at first, just scroll down for a more detailed description)Pro:-Great level design-Campaign plays smooth-Great humor and jokes between the missions-Steam Workshop offers a long-term playabilityContra:-Story line is just about 2 hours long-Story isn't that replayable in my opinion it becomes boring too fast-Decisions do not affect the ending, but it doesn't make the game linearSide Note:So I bought the game at the release date andI was satisfied with the game UNTIL the story campaign was over.Many people in the review section may had complained about the issue before.They were longing for a missing feature for a long time, but now after a year of waiting it's avaible; STEAM WORKSHOP!Story:You play a charakter called "Conway",he's a person whose a type of hacking contract killer bulgar.Who just got another contract, what he doesn't know is, he is going on a big one this time.Gameplay:Conway has unique equipment, whereas I tell you the most useful and main gadget of  the game: the "crosslink" tool. It's therefore to connect every interactable object to another -e.g. A switch to a door-, with this gadget you can interact with your surroundings and reach the objective; hacking and stealing sensitive data. As in stealing this data, you will have to get to the data container first, which is for example: a computer which is in posses of information, which in turn your client needs.Just expect that and a lot more.Workshop:Steam Workshop offers about an amount of 500 levels at the first two weeks of its release.It's incredible how quickly the game turned me on again, I really wanted to play the game after a year again.Level Editor:Making your own levels is pretty simple, you only have to click on the "Level Editor" option in the menu, and you are good to go. Though, you don't get access to all the features in the level editor.Therefore we have "PointEdit", a level editor which has every item of the game included.Rating:A clear 9.5/10, due to the Steam Workshop.
