												Charming, funny and clever. Three words that are usually the signs of a well-made game.Whilst it's not going to keep you up at night racking your brain on how to beat that ONE level, it's enough of a challenge to keep your brain ticking over.A standard 2D stealth-em-up with a novel twist, the game encourages and rewards creativity, although if you get frustrated, there's always the option to go charging in as well. The dialogue between missions bounces from pretty amusing to out-and-out hilarious without ever compromising a story that becomes more interesting and less 'token' than you may think at first glance.Personally, this is well worth your money if you have even a passing interest in this sort of game. A very pleasant impulse buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												So in one sentence, this game had unique mechanics, amusing dialog, and was fun to play but was surprisingly short. You start out with the power to super jump which you can use to tackle guards and crash through windows, and you start adding other gadgets to your arsenal. The most significant to gameplay allows you to re-route circuits in the levels to activate different types of objects. So for example, you can re-route a lightswitch to open a locked door, assuming you have access to that circuit. This gives each level a bit of a sandbox were you can do silly stuff, like rigging the elevator so that when it opens, it turns off a light, and when the guard tries to turn off the light, he'll inadvertently unlock a door for you by flipping a switch. These rube-goldberg-esque solutions aren't usually the most practical way to play the game, but are usually the most fun.I was going for all objectives, no kills, no noise just like I usually do with stealth-type games, and still beat the game in like 3 hours or something, all told. Usually this playstyle makes my playtimes really long, but not so with Gunpoint.  It does have a level editor, so if you're into hidden value, it might be there, and I think that there's tons and tons of unexplored design territory for budding puzzle designers. So while I do recommend Gunpoint, it's hard to recommend at full price. They did a good job tying everything together with a story, but a couple dozen cheaply made puzzle levels would've really added to the game's value and would've been a totally welcome post-game unlock like some kind of challenge mode.Some friends might chastise me for this caveat against an indie developer, but as fun as the mechanics are, I feel like they under-utilized what they had.

content:

												GunPoint is a welcome title amongst all the High Def, 3D, indepth titles we see now.  It is refreashing too see that some game developers remember the roots of iconic pixel games.  But it's not just the nastalgia that makes Gunpoint unique.  It's the complex puzzles required for completing a mission.  There are multiple ways of completing a mission, either way is preferable.  From hiding in the dark to knocking the guards off a 5 story building through the window.  The game includes a unique story that adds some witty humor.  From jumping out of the building to talking with yoru clients.What makes the game stand out are the puzzles.  You need to work your way through various guards and security cameras in order too accomplish your goal.  Hacking terminals, doors, cameras and even the pistols of the guards.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												The beauty of Gunpoint is its simplicity: the visuals are low-fi, but the gameplay is decidedly high-tech. Equipped with mechanical trousers that permit you to leap tall buildings in a--well, a couple of bounds--you assume the role of a detective caught up in a murder conspiracy, armed with only your pants and a couple of upgrades. It's one of the most deliciously well-written, atmospheric, and satisfying puzzlers I've played in a long time. VISUALS: Simple and clean, pixel-art that communicates the environment without any clutter to distract you from the gameplay. SOUND/MUSIC: The tunes in this game are legitimately good listening all on their own, but they add a noir ambience that is undeniably a character unto itself. GAMEPLAY: Aside from acrobatic feats, you can use a wiremapping device to re-wire entire buildings, so that a light-switch in one room might short a light socket in another--and thereby electrocute and pacify a patrolling guard. There are many opportunities for game-breaking shenanigans here. Add in a level creator and you've got room for plenty of replayability. Great stealth-action title, very funny, highly recommended.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Amazing, I have never been so intrigued to write a review for a game that I purchased for $2.99. Shifting through the 2016 Summer Sale, I came across a rather "impulse buy" and a knowledgeable one. I had purchased Gunpoint on a late night after I had finished my final exams, I was up to try something I've never heard of, something that I would never think of buying. I installed and played Gunpoint for about 3 and a half hours, I finished majority of the campaign and unlocked almost everything. I have to say, it was a huge refreshment to play Gunpoint. The amazing and hilarious dialog made me laugh so much that I wanted to replay the campaign for a second time to see the different dialogs I could trigger. If that wasn't funny enough for you, check out the achievements. On the other hand the gameplay was solid and simple, creating a feeling of "more than what meets the eye" type of game. Other than that, All I could say is that Gunpoint is a short little fun game that you should pick up on sale. It's going to be worth the price with high replay value.

												Even if it wasn't for the 'overwhelmingly positive reviews' it has to be said that it's a really great game.In a nutshell: you're a freelance spy and you can act it out however you please. Be a ninja, an avid fan of noise and violence or a genius electrician.. if not a bit of everything. The dialogue is very amusing to say the least and the story in itself is pretty solid. Really, the only possible downside I can think of is that it's pretty short, which isn't that bad considering you may want to give it another playthrough to make different choices. And if that's not enough for replayability there's always the Steam Workshop/level editor to create and play custom levels.I'd say it has more than enough charm to justify it's price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												A simple, short game about a spy with no allegiances who's just trying to keep himself from getting screwed over and make some money. Gunpoint's strategy with a stealth element and it's game mecahnics are what really makes the game unique. They are fascinating because they make you think in terms of open and closed circuts - e.g. object A does this which triggers object B and electrocutes a guard. While it's easy to catch on, it's not so easy that mental effort isn't required - I'd say medium on the challenging scale. If just doing the bare minimum, one can finish this game in a matter of hours, but there are extra achievements possible for doing levels with a specific style or speed if that's your kind of thing. The dialogue is cute and made me laugh. While it's not an adventure game per say, you are given a few choices that will affect the game. And the ability to choose different dialogue options in between missions made me feel more invested in my character. (For example, I made my character as snarky as possible.) The music is well done and quite fitting, as is the 16-bit design; both really help to aid the cloak and dagger atmosphere for our spy protagonist. All in all it's a cute little indie game that's definitely worth getting on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Gunpoint was the very first indie game I ever bought. Ever since then I've been an avid fan of all sorts of indie games that comprise of such attention to detail and atmosphere as Gunpoint. Some additional features were added like the Steam workshop, and there was even a time you could get a refund back in in early 2014 because the developer didn't think he would be able to pull through to add Steam worshop. Late 2014 and Steam workshop was added. The reason this was very important, because with Steam workshop, the amount of levels are now endless, and you can now create your own levels and share them with the Steam community. Before you were stuck replaying the same levels over and over again just to get the best possible rating. Which is another cool feature in Gunpoint, every time you complete a level, you get a rating, obviously, stealth, and non-violence will only earn you the best rating possible. Undoubtly, Gunpoint is one of the best indie games I've ever played, and I'll certainly say it is one of the few games that pioneered and paved the way for other indie games of similar quality to follow.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Very funny game!I was lucky enough to be invloved in the very early testing of this game when it was being developed and I have to say that I'm very impressed with how it has progressed from a very simple concept of hacking, jumping falling and punching (and punching and punching and punching etc..).The diolouge throughout the campaign was hilarious and the multichoice made it all come together.Mechanics-wise: The game plays very smoothly. I find my self smiling when I pull of jumping around from ceiling to wall to another walls and behind a patroling guard and then proceed to punch him into oblivion and it all working out just as I'd hoped. I also love the "OH CRAP!" moments when that exact situation turns out to be a complete failure whether it be due to me jumping straight infront of the guard and starting in shock like a deer in the headlights or whether it was my fault for not disabling a sound sensor or even more hilariously, forgetting that I've linked the guards gun to an electrical output which is where I happen to be standing at that very moment.This is truly a game that leaves it up to the player, but never loses its charm no matter how you play it.Although the campaign is only about 2hrs, it has a level editor with steamworkshop support so enjoy playing other users levels :)Definitely recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												One of the best (out of the view) indie games I've ever played. Great story and plot that let's the player make his/hers own decisions on how to progress and how the story will unfold. Beautiful soundtrack that really makes you feel like an old fashioned detective. Funny achievements and allows for the player to decide whether he will complete the mission with stealth or to just fight his way through a building, sneak through the shadows or hang on the ceiling waiting to pounce on an unsuspecting guard? No matter which way you play it, Gunpoint is worth the purchase. Kinda wish the story lasted longer, but remember you can always just go back and finish the story in a completely different way or complete missions differently!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												It's fun. It's different. It takes a little getting used to. But it's... Disapointingly short. I remember playing the demo and thinking that this was going to be a fantastic game... And well... it is and it isn't.  It took me less than 3 hours to 100% the game, minus a few odds and ends achievements that I could go back and do in less than 10 minutes. Don't buy this if you expect a good value for your money, because 5 dollars an hour is more expensive than the average movie time to price value. Laughably easy, a story that seems shoehorned in to try and keep the gameplay in line and a gadget variety so small you really do feel like a spy on a budget. Don't expect the gameplay to change from switching light switches to doors and cameras to doors until the last level, where a 'big' surprise lies in wait for you. (Hint: It's not that big, but it changes how you can tackle early levels.)Shortcap: In less than 3 hours you can A+ every level, get 95% of the achievements and crush the story without mercy. Not worth 10 bucks, but 5 dollars or less it's a solid buy, especially if you're a big supporter of indie games.I'm a little disapointed by the creator, as this game could have gone seriously far. I hope to see a sequel or better yet, a free expansion that adds some content.I give it a 2.5 out of 5 stars.

If you like puzzles with creative solutions you won't regret buying this, though you might want to wait until the planned full rewrite of the game is done and it's integrated into the Steam Workshop, which will no doubt extend the longevity of the game like 10k%. Try the demo - short but sweet.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												It's fun. It's different. It takes a little getting used to. But it's... Disapointingly short. I remember playing the demo and thinking that this was going to be a fantastic game... And well... it is and it isn't.  It took me less than 3 hours to 100% the game, minus a few odds and ends achievements that I could go back and do in less than 10 minutes. Don't buy this if you expect a good value for your money, because 5 dollars an hour is more expensive than the average movie time to price value. Laughably easy, a story that seems shoehorned in to try and keep the gameplay in line and a gadget variety so small you really do feel like a spy on a budget. Don't expect the gameplay to change from switching light switches to doors and cameras to doors until the last level, where a 'big' surprise lies in wait for you. (Hint: It's not that big, but it changes how you can tackle early levels.)Shortcap: In less than 3 hours you can A+ every level, get 95% of the achievements and crush the story without mercy. Not worth 10 bucks, but 5 dollars or less it's a solid buy, especially if you're a big supporter of indie games.I'm a little disapointed by the creator, as this game could have gone seriously far. I hope to see a sequel or better yet, a free expansion that adds some content.I give it a 2.5 out of 5 stars.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												I bought this a while back, when it was on sale, and never really looked at it again. Today I loaded it up, dived in and found a game that realised what made a good puzzle game, ingenuity. You see, you don't have all that much in the way of abilities, apart from being able to jump really high (and fall from great heights safely), being able to punch people out in one hit, and a habit of dying after being hit with anything remotely bulletlike from any angle (although that last one might just be common sense). Soon you get the ability to rewire electronics, which is where the game shines. Each level presents itself as a maze of sorts, where you can open close, break or otherwise wreak havoc with various objects in some remarkably clever ways, all through a simple set of controls.I know it says stealth up there, but that's really kind of optional. You do kind of have to go the stealthy route (since, again, one bullet = death) you can either be noisy or quiet, or most often a mix of the both. But its rewarding, and doesn't really value one over the other. You can spend a minute setting up a connection so that a door whacks a guard in the face as he walks through it, or you run up behind him and knock him out a window, or come the other way through said window, send glass flying everywhere, land on the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and beat him until the floor is covered in a fine red sludge. Or you could, you know, just go past whilst he's not looking. Your choiceThe only real problem I have is that its not very long. I finished it in 3 and a bit hours, and whilst there's a level editor (and presumably the ability to download other people's levels) that might not add too much. Its good, but short.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												Gunpoint is a stealth puzzle game just as the developer says, and is a very competent game as well. The game boils down to its two main mechanics and ties in a detective story with some humor too. With some simple gameplay mechanics, the level design is done in such a way to take full advantage of your toolset for some invigorating puzzles and stealth.The story in Gunpoint revolves around freelance spy Richard Conway, as he tries to clear his name from someone’s murder and solve a murder mystery. The majority of the story is told through messages on Conway’s phone, and this is where the humor comes in. You the player are given multiple dialog options, and several of Conway’s responses are snarky or bizarre in context. Whichever response is picked, there’s bound to be some good laughs at the overall script and the player dialog. In the main game there are a few choices to be made. They do change the story slightly, though the levels remain mostly the same. Anyhow, the strong film noir story works out fine with some excellent humor mixed in, along with good variety in dialog responses and story choices to mix things up.Gunpoint’s stealth puzzle gameplay is in two distinct pieces. The first is the Bullfrog, a set of trousers that allow Conway to leap really tall distances and at a high speed. Conway can also pounce on enemies and punch them either to knock them out or to death. The second is the Crosslink, a tool to hack and rewire electrical components together to solve puzzles. These two components are the basis for the puzzles and stealth of the game, with the levels strongly using these mechanics in interesting ways. Throughout the game, unlocks can be received, either through using skill points for upgrading the Bullfrog and battery system or for unlocking new abilities. The new abilities tie in closely with the core mechanics, and serve to augment certain playstyles players may have as they complete each level. The levels and abilities serve multiple kinds of solutions, whether it be violent engagements or undetected stealth. With these two gameplay mechanics and great level design that gives players multiple ways to solve them, Gunpoint’s stealth puzzle gameplay is quite open ended on giving players freedom using just these two main tools.The art style of Gunpoint is a 2d pixelated style. The world of Gunpoint is pretty well detailed, while still having a pixel art style that isn’t too retro. The environments do a great job in expressing the film noir style with the different buildings and the urban setting, with relatively simple character and object models to make gameplay streamlined with easy to see designs. Overall it’s a mix of good detail in the buildings and backgrounds, with more simple designs on characters and objects to easily stick out in gameplay.The music of Gunpoint is an excellent jazzy soundtrack. Since this game is heavily inspired by film noir, it would only be natural to have the music reflect that style. Each of the music pieces range from slower songs played in the menu or during the phone dialog, to faster songs well suited to the espionage during gameplay. The songs played during gameplay have essentially two versions, one when the view is normal and the other when Crosslink mode is active. It’s a very nice touch that helps to identify which mode the player is in, and suits the current display too with a more electronic style when hacking along with the jazzy style while in the main view. The music of Gunpoint brings in some nice sounding jazz that sounds great while playing through both the story and gameplay sections.Gunpoint takes stealth puzzle gameplay with its two main mechanics: leaping and hacking. The game takes these concepts and uses them in new ways with its levels and unlockable abilities. Alongside that is a film noir story that packs some solid humor with both the overall script and possible dialog choices. To tie the game together are a fitting detailed pixel art style and a solid jazz soundtrack that makes gameplay fun and fitting to the theme. Gunpoint plays well with these elements for a unique game experience that is fun to play through along with some bright ideas for some smart game design.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												It is difficult not to compare 'Gunpoint' and 'Watch_Dogs'. I played 'Watch_Dogs' before 'Gunpoint', with the latter released about a year and half earlier. I liked 'Watch_Dogs'; it's good (but not $69.99 good, making me feel lucky that I got my free copy from nVidia), but I feel that it is not as polished as it could have been and some features could have been implemented better.This brings us to 'Gunpoint', which ironically features less guns than 'Watch_Dogs'. Both games require players to use hacking as a tool to solve puzzles, but 'Gunpoint' implements the hacking better and is a more polished game. Its game design actually puts hacking into the forefront and encourages players to complete the game in a stealthy, non-lethal and even non-violent ways. You need to think creatively to solve the puzzles, especially if you aim for an A or A+ rating. Completing a mission with a high rating is, therefore, very rewarding. The game's replayability is very high as it also includes a level editor.On the other hand, the hacking in 'Watch_Dogs', while fun at times, seems like an afterthought and gimmicky. In some 'Watch_Dogs' missions, it is often easier to shoot than to hack your way out of a difficult situation. I think most people will agree with me that the best parts of 'Watch_Dogs' are ones where your hacking skills and wit are your only disposable tools. 'Gunpoint' is pretty much all these "best parts", making it a superior game to 'Watch_Dogs' overall.Needless to say, I highly recommend 'Gunpoint'. It is a well-made game and it is one of the best puzzle games I have played. If you are interested in 'Watch_Dogs', well, get it when it costs $30 or less. Like I said before, I enjoyed 'Watch_Dogs', but I think your time will be better spent if you play 'Gunpoint' instead.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Gunpoint is like a mix of Hotline Miami, Mark of the Ninja, and Arkham Asylum. You're a corporate spy in a 2-D world trying to solve a murder that you unwittingly pin on yourself. Each mission involves avoiding or knocking out guards, re-wiring electrical systems, smashing through windows, and hanging off the walls like Batman. You can jump ultra-high too without hurting yourself. Late in the game you can pull out your gun, but I don't recommend it.You gain abilities by purchasing them in the store, and take missions for a variety of (competing) clients. You communicate with them via text message, and the conversations are often hilarious. They may have a variety of requests - complete the mission without hurting anyone, or kill everyone, or be completely silent.Manipulating the various buildings is simple but extremely fun, and doesn't get old for the three hours it takes to beat the game. Given the length it might be a stretch to recommend this one at full price, but at $5 or less it's a no-brainer.Some performance notes: it's more demanding than a 2-d pixel art game warrants. My 2010 Macbook couldn't play it, despite meeting the minimum Mac requirements. I have 4.6 hours of playtime because the first 1.6 hours were spent struggling to try to play it on the Macbook before I gave up and played it on my main rig.

												This is a game where you leap thirty feet into the air through a window to tackle a guard, then magically re-wire another guard's gun so that when he tries to shoot you it instead slams a door on a third guard two floors down, knocking him unconcious. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												This is a stealth game about rewiring things and punching people.  And it's a great game.Each mission, you're asked to break into a building and reach a computer terminal.  To do this, you need to figure out how to rewire circuits to open the correct doors, while avoiding being shot in the face.  This gives the game a pseudo-puzzle-game feel.  However, if you don't feel like solving puzzles, or are just a generally violent person, you also have the option of pushing the guards out the windows or beating them with your fists.The best part of this game though is the dialog.  Dear lord that dialog.  Whereas I usually skim over dialog for most games, in this game I found myself genuinely looking forward to the between-mission cutscenes, because the choices you're given are so funny.  I laughed every time.  Every time.My only complaint is that the game was so short.  It took me 3 hours to beat the first time, and 2 hours to beat a second and get all the achievements.  I don't normally recommend such short games, but I enjoyed the gameplay and humor so much I feel it was worth the cost, even at full-price.9/10

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Very funny game!I was lucky enough to be invloved in the very early testing of this game when it was being developed and I have to say that I'm very impressed with how it has progressed from a very simple concept of hacking, jumping falling and punching (and punching and punching and punching etc..).The diolouge throughout the campaign was hilarious and the multichoice made it all come together.Mechanics-wise: The game plays very smoothly. I find my self smiling when I pull of jumping around from ceiling to wall to another walls and behind a patroling guard and then proceed to punch him into oblivion and it all working out just as I'd hoped. I also love the "OH CRAP!" moments when that exact situation turns out to be a complete failure whether it be due to me jumping straight infront of the guard and starting in shock like a deer in the headlights or whether it was my fault for not disabling a sound sensor or even more hilariously, forgetting that I've linked the guards gun to an electrical output which is where I happen to be standing at that very moment.This is truly a game that leaves it up to the player, but never loses its charm no matter how you play it.Although the campaign is only about 2hrs, it has a level editor with steamworkshop support so enjoy playing other users levels :)Definitely recommended.

Posted: April 26, 2016
												Gunpoint is a good game with a good story. On paper, it might seem difficult, but it's actually pretty easy once you understand the hacking mechanics. It's on the short side, so you can breeze right through it in a few hours.The story revolves around a freelance espionage agent that is startled by a murder in a building next to his apartment building. He only ends up investigating it because he sets off these new spring shoes he bought which launches him into the murder building. Conway ends up being part of a conspiracy and helps track down the real killer why also figuring out why the victim was killed.Good game. Good soundtrack.8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Gunpoint is like a mix of Hotline Miami, Mark of the Ninja, and Arkham Asylum. You're a corporate spy in a 2-D world trying to solve a murder that you unwittingly pin on yourself. Each mission involves avoiding or knocking out guards, re-wiring electrical systems, smashing through windows, and hanging off the walls like Batman. You can jump ultra-high too without hurting yourself. Late in the game you can pull out your gun, but I don't recommend it.You gain abilities by purchasing them in the store, and take missions for a variety of (competing) clients. You communicate with them via text message, and the conversations are often hilarious. They may have a variety of requests - complete the mission without hurting anyone, or kill everyone, or be completely silent.Manipulating the various buildings is simple but extremely fun, and doesn't get old for the three hours it takes to beat the game. Given the length it might be a stretch to recommend this one at full price, but at $5 or less it's a no-brainer.Some performance notes: it's more demanding than a 2-d pixel art game warrants. My 2010 Macbook couldn't play it, despite meeting the minimum Mac requirements. I have 4.6 hours of playtime because the first 1.6 hours were spent struggling to try to play it on the Macbook before I gave up and played it on my main rig.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												Gunpoint is a stealth puzzle game just as the developer says, and is a very competent game as well. The game boils down to its two main mechanics and ties in a detective story with some humor too. With some simple gameplay mechanics, the level design is done in such a way to take full advantage of your toolset for some invigorating puzzles and stealth.The story in Gunpoint revolves around freelance spy Richard Conway, as he tries to clear his name from someone’s murder and solve a murder mystery. The majority of the story is told through messages on Conway’s phone, and this is where the humor comes in. You the player are given multiple dialog options, and several of Conway’s responses are snarky or bizarre in context. Whichever response is picked, there’s bound to be some good laughs at the overall script and the player dialog. In the main game there are a few choices to be made. They do change the story slightly, though the levels remain mostly the same. Anyhow, the strong film noir story works out fine with some excellent humor mixed in, along with good variety in dialog responses and story choices to mix things up.Gunpoint’s stealth puzzle gameplay is in two distinct pieces. The first is the Bullfrog, a set of trousers that allow Conway to leap really tall distances and at a high speed. Conway can also pounce on enemies and punch them either to knock them out or to death. The second is the Crosslink, a tool to hack and rewire electrical components together to solve puzzles. These two components are the basis for the puzzles and stealth of the game, with the levels strongly using these mechanics in interesting ways. Throughout the game, unlocks can be received, either through using skill points for upgrading the Bullfrog and battery system or for unlocking new abilities. The new abilities tie in closely with the core mechanics, and serve to augment certain playstyles players may have as they complete each level. The levels and abilities serve multiple kinds of solutions, whether it be violent engagements or undetected stealth. With these two gameplay mechanics and great level design that gives players multiple ways to solve them, Gunpoint’s stealth puzzle gameplay is quite open ended on giving players freedom using just these two main tools.The art style of Gunpoint is a 2d pixelated style. The world of Gunpoint is pretty well detailed, while still having a pixel art style that isn’t too retro. The environments do a great job in expressing the film noir style with the different buildings and the urban setting, with relatively simple character and object models to make gameplay streamlined with easy to see designs. Overall it’s a mix of good detail in the buildings and backgrounds, with more simple designs on characters and objects to easily stick out in gameplay.The music of Gunpoint is an excellent jazzy soundtrack. Since this game is heavily inspired by film noir, it would only be natural to have the music reflect that style. Each of the music pieces range from slower songs played in the menu or during the phone dialog, to faster songs well suited to the espionage during gameplay. The songs played during gameplay have essentially two versions, one when the view is normal and the other when Crosslink mode is active. It’s a very nice touch that helps to identify which mode the player is in, and suits the current display too with a more electronic style when hacking along with the jazzy style while in the main view. The music of Gunpoint brings in some nice sounding jazz that sounds great while playing through both the story and gameplay sections.Gunpoint takes stealth puzzle gameplay with its two main mechanics: leaping and hacking. The game takes these concepts and uses them in new ways with its levels and unlockable abilities. Alongside that is a film noir story that packs some solid humor with both the overall script and possible dialog choices. To tie the game together are a fitting detailed pixel art style and a solid jazz soundtrack that makes gameplay fun and fitting to the theme. Gunpoint plays well with these elements for a unique game experience that is fun to play through along with some bright ideas for some smart game design.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												This is one of my favourite videogames ever.It's like someone took a Raymond Chandler novel, made it self-aware enough to be cute and funny, and incidentally made it a puzzle videogame set in a cyberpunk future with nice pixel art.The aesthetic is very much film-noir inspired with cyberpunk elements just slightly tinting the edges. Don't think kaleidoscopic William Gibson-esque punks with giant purple mohawks and uzis. Instead, think spies in huge trenchcoats carrying a couple of high-tech gadgets and smartphones. Think cigar-chewing shirt and suspenders wearing boors who don't give a damn who gets hurt but no ♥♥♥♥ing witnesses, capisce? Think handsome men in fashionable sweaters with precisely trendy haircuts patiently and articulately explaining to you why you need to let them get away with ruining that person's life and isn't this such a large suitcase full of money? You could do things with that. Think elegant dames with perfect glamour who spend every spare moment of their waking lives thinking up ever more untraceable ways to utterly destroy a man. You'd have to be an idiot to betray her.The soundtrack is gorgeous. Each level has two soundtracks: its main track, which is tense jazz, and a second mirror version that the game slips into when you switch to hacking mode, with a more electronic sound. Each level's music creates a variation on the same feeling: that here before us is an intently dangerous problem of immense personal importance to us, upon which we are bringing to bear powerful tools, strength and cleverness and (in the hacking/electronic version) willfully indiscriminate application of being a GIANT FREAKING NERD.The player character is witty, stylish, slightly lacking in common sense, has good taste in hats, he's called "Richard" and he's just a little bit of a knob without really meaning to be. I like him.The writing is phenominal. It's like VtM: Bloodlines in that there are a cast of varied, interesting characters who have intricate relationships with one another and the player character, interesting goals and motivations and good reasons for hating one another, which is why they're paying you to untraceably destroy that other character's life. There are jokes which are both cheesy and funny. The art and writing interplay with one another in ways where one will swoop in to reinforce or take the mick out of what the other just did.The hacking parts are like someone finally made a game version of @internetofshit - these buildings all contain a menagerie of faulty devices that are plugged into the internet and shouldn't be, and you get to arbitrarily screw with the inhabitants at will by suborning their gadgets. See https://twitter.com/internetofshit for inspiration.The puzzles all make sense. Impressively, this is a puzzle game that never makes you feel dumb, but also rewards cleverness. Some levels will take some studying but none are frustrating and you can always make a tradeoff between how long you want to spend thinking about each level and how sloppy, risky or violent you want to be. Most levels admit multiple solutions, some sneakier and some faster or more violent. Doing a real pacifist run is both challenging and fun.Notably, in a world where most videogame morality is a conflict between "rescue kitten" and "kill and eat kitten", Gunpoint does not arbitrarily punish the player for using violence, but at the same time it does not omit consequences for it and it does not let you forget that you've used it.I did not encounter any interestingly bad bugs in this game. It's possible (but rare) to trigger physics glitches that let you bypass obstacles in some levels. The experience of seeing your character's blog post at the end is not seamless because it closes the game to open a browser for you? Meh. I haven't

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												I have to admit I am generally not a huge fan of indie games, but this one works for me. The graphics, as you can tell, are not that stellar, but it works well in the context of the game.I would characterize the game as a puzzle game, with the main goal trying to figure out how to open the various doors without getting shot. The game is designed very well, with auto-save checkpoints letting you go back a couple seconds, so you are not penalized for dying and experimenting. I wish more games were like this as redoing the same thing over and over is not very fun. As you progress through the game you will unlock new techs which can drastically change the strategies available - this adds some re-playability to the game. The game takes 4-5 hours to beat, which for me is a perfect length - long enough to understand the depth, but short enough that the story isn't drawn out for no good reason.Overall, 8/10.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												This game is a masterpiece, don't let the 3-hour campaign fool you, there's a cacaphony of user-generated content that will keep you busy for days. The story, if you pay attention to it, is written well enough so that you care about the characters while mixing in some well-placed humor for good effect. The in-game dialogue lets you choose what the player character, Conway, says in between jobs, and I often found myself torn between selecting the hard-boiled bit of dialogue or the less serious, more hilarious option.I got this game for $3 and ended up wishing I spent the full 10. Gunpoint is a game that'll stick with you for a long while, and I won't soon remove it from my steam library.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												A comedic take on the Noir style, this 2D puzzle-platformer knows how to introduce jokes into an otherwise serious, game. It starts off with a murder, and you need to figure out not who did it, but why. At the end of the first mission, there's an admittedly funny scene that shows you how you got your first piece of equipment, and then you're told that there is evidence you're the killer, but you obviously aren't.As I mentioned, the game in general is fun, both to play and to read. There are several achievements were the developpers make some obviously cheesy jokes, like one where you beat a guy a bunch of times, but they really work if its your first time experiencing them. The controls are easy to learn, and there is more than one way to stealthily finish a level. The new Worhkshop integration lets users create their own levels, some of which are admittedly creative and harder than the ones in the game. It's short and direct, so it leaves you wanting the more it doesn't have, which is filled by thr Workshop levels. About halfway through, there's a mission that lets you take one of two choices, either supporting the innocent company or helping out the guilty one. There's also a different mission where you can tell, or not, the bad guy that you were contracted to steal from him.[/spolier] I definitely want there to be a sequel, and this is definitely worth the $10.10/10

The narrative is linear yet clever and witty, the mechanics are somewhat unique, the main character has sass for days and it doesn't take itself serious. It doesn't take long to complete (3 to 4 hours), but every stage seems thought-out and relevant. So if you like stealth games with a little bit of creative thinking, this is definitely something for you. I definitely recommend this game and will play it again!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Gunpoint is a puzzle game with platforming and stealth elements.The 'puzzles' come in the form of an incredibly unique, fun, and interesting rewiring system, where you can make one thing connect to another.For example, you can open a door with a switch.It is amazing. One of the most clever and enjoyable mechanics I've ever had the joy of performing.There are many fun upgrades you can buy for your character, Conway. Anything from increasing the height you can jump (did i mention you can jump super high in this game? its awesome) to kicking down doors.Every upgrade is fun in its own unique way and is worth your attention at some point.The game isn't open world but it has a workshop page, full of user-created levels, that you can also create if you please.The game has a little replayability as there is different play styles.In short, the gameplay is absolutely amazing.There's a lot more to Gunpoint then jumping around and rewiring, though.There is an extremely captivating, motivating, and interesting story that actually interested me from the moment I started the game to the end.I'm not gonna spoil a thing because it's something everyone should experience without being spoiled.But it was the best story in a game I've ever experienced since The Walking Dead.The charm in this game is constantly present.There wasn't a single moment in this game that I didn't have a smile on my face.During the dialouge there are some lines that actually made my chest hurt from laughing so hard.Even while you are in the middle of a mission the charm is present.When you are first prompted to punch a guard, being the person I am, I punched him in the face a remarkable amount of times. To my surprise messages kept popping up, eventually even keeping count of how many times you've punched the guard in the face and rightfully chastising you for it.Hell, at the end of the game, you get to pick what things your character will put in his blog post that summarizes the case. When you hit sumbit a real, existing, web page is created, containing the content you chose. And it's great.In short, Gunpoint is actually my favorite game I've played in a long, long time.Amazing gameplay.Amazing story.Amazing charm.Amazing game.10/10.A must-buy.My blog post: (CONTAINS MASSIVE SPOILERS, DO NOT VISIT UNLESS YOU HAVE COMPLETED THE GAME. I MEAN IT.) http://www.pentadact.com/category/conwaysblog/?K=21&U=39&C0=3&E1=1&C1=2&E2=3&C2=5&C3=3&C4=3&C5=3

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												Picked this up on sale and is definitely worth the cost. Offers a short story, offering multiple perspectives and giving you choices along the way, although somewhat limited. As you progress you can unlock new gadgets that will be required for future story missions.  All around the gameplay is really fluid and well done, and you can probably get through the story in about 3 hours, give or take. Alongside the story, there is also a level editor, and the ability to play other user-made levels.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												This is a game where you leap thirty feet into the air through a window to tackle a guard, then magically re-wire another guard's gun so that when he tries to shoot you it instead slams a door on a third guard two floors down, knocking him unconcious.  It is not a game where you do a lot of anything at gunpoint, and in fact if you do finally obtain a gun you only get a handful of bullets and can never get more.  Try to get through all the levels without hurting anyone!  Try to knock out as many guards as you can without ever entering the building!  Make your own levels with a mostly-okay level editor!  Enjoy the genuinely hilarious dialogue! This is a game you can buy using money, and you should do that.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Gunpoint is a mixture of action and puzzle with stealth mechanics. It has a level creator so you can create your own levels to play and mess around with the physics of the game(or you could just make one door that you kick down on all the guards, killing them all instantaneously). In the story the game gives you 2-3 choices of diologue so not every ending will be the same. But honestly, I wouldn't have played the whole story in one sitting if it wasn't for that third choice, which was definitely the most smartass choice you could possibly pick. Won't spoil it for ya- just kidding. John dies at the end.

												Very amazing game for me! Nowadays we have a hundreds of 3D games of all kind - shooters, RPG's, action games, racing simulators, etc... All these are cool. content:
Posted: August 26, 2013
												Gunpoint is a retro platformer in which you rewire electronics to fool guards and progress through levels. You use an array of upgradable and purchasable (yes, only in-game money - this isn't EA) gadgets to accomplish a plethora of tasks. Via these gadgets, you can jump onto walls, ceilings, or through glass - and then you can rewire a guards pistol to turn off the lights when the trigger is pulled. Everything was very fun and was quite innovative.The writing in Gunpoint is one of its strong points, for sure. The story is both good and quite funny, I laughed (hard) quite a bit through the game. Just the sounds and motions of you accidentally crashing through a window are absolutely hilarious.Although the game uses the increasingly generic retro style, the designers did a fairly good job incorporating it - even the point where I really couldn't imagine Gunpoint looking any different. The soundtrack is quite good as well, I found it to be very fitting.Overall, I recommend that you buy this game. Although it only lasts for a few hours, there are multiple endings, so there is some replayability. Even given the short length, I feel that Gunpoint is completely worth it at its current $10 price.Before I end this, I'd like to thank my friend Rocky Raccoon for gifting me this game out of the blue. You're awesome!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Gunpoint, one of my favorite games as of late. Let's go over some of the main parts of the game. First off, let me say that while I have low hours, that is because this is a game that most people can complete in one sitting, but it is a very satisfying one sitting.__Alright, so here's the rundown of the very absolute basics of Gunpoint.Gunpoint is a fairly unique game. You play as a noir-style freelance spy named Richard Conway that can leap very far, cling and climb on walls and ceilings, and can survive long falls thanks to what the game explains simply as advanced equipment your character possesses. In every level, you must infiltrate a building to get to the goal (which is almost always a computer you must hack) and get back out without the guards shooting you. Guards can see you and you will not lose, unlike some other stealth games.__Now, for some of the more clever mechanics in the game.A big part of getting in and out of the buildings in Gunpoint is the Crosslink. Once you have the Crosslink after the first few tutorial levels, you can switch into Crosslink mode quickly and smoothy by rolling your mousewheel down a click. Every device in Gunpoint uses wiring systems, and in Crosslink mode you can rewire any device to any other device. Wire a lightswitch to a hand scanner that wires to a door, and when you hit the switch the end result is the door opening. Wire a guard's weapon into a power socket he's standing near, and when he tries to fire it the socket will overload and shock him.You can't wire a guard's gun right at the start of the game, however. There are upgrades you can to get from the ingame store (all of the upgrades become available fairly quickly), one of which being the ability to wire guns. Other abilities are things like being able to go through a window without making a loud noise, and there are more unique purchases, such as the Resolver, the only gun you can use in the game.Guards can be snuck past (my personal favorite way is to cling to the ceiling above them as they patrol), taken down by leaping at them and knocking them out with a punch, or killed by tackling them out a window (or punching them several times, if you're excessive like that). As said before, you can use more creative ways of knocking out a guard, like with power sockets. There are multiple types of guards, some are the standard that can be easly tackled to remove, some a more advanced kind that can only be taken out through more robust methods. All guards shoot on sight, which can be a bit finnicky at times (specifically after you get the upgrade that makes them sometimes miss) but overall works very well. A single bullet will kill you instantly, but the game has a very good checkpoint system, autosaving your position every few seconds. This allows you to jump back a little ways if you make a mistake without restarting the whole level, or allows you to restart the whole thing if you decide on a different approach.__The ExperienceA general level goes like this: You start off the left of a building. First you must find a way in, either through diving into a window or finding a way to open a door (or entering into an already-open door). You need to open the doors to the computer you want to hack on the third floor, but it runs on blue wiring, and you only start with red. You must sneak hijack the blue wirebox on the first floor in order to manipulate the blue wires on the third. After a quick look over the building, you decide the best way to get in is by leaping through a window on the second floor. However, doing so would alert the guard, who will shoot you on sight. There happens to be a camera outside the building, and a light in the room the guard is in. You wire the camera to the light, then go under the camera. The light turns off, and the guard wanders into the next room over, looking for the lightswitch. You quickly leap into the window while his back is turned and dash down to the first floor, right as the lights come on. In the first floor, you quickly leap into the guard before he turns around and knock him out. After that, you can get to the blue wirebox, allowing you to manipulate the doors on the third floor. You sneak back up past the guard on the second floor, up to floor three, where you open the doors by wiring the blue lightswitch to the blue door. After that, you dash through the window on the third floor and make your escape off stage right.__The StoryWhen you accept a mission, there is a brief dialogue between Conway and whoever is giving you the mission. You can choose many dialogue options for different paths in the game (the paths, however, do not really change level layouts and mostly affect dialogue options). There is also a dialogue scene like this after you complete a mission. The story is a murder-mystery noir-styled tale that will quickly grab your interest and keep you begging for a resolve. For this reason, I cannot go into specific depth on the story, but I will say this is one of the strongest points of the game. You could make a movie out of it, and it would be awesome.I will say, and I only say this because it happens right at the beginning, how the story starts.--PLEASE DON'T READ THIS IF YOU ALREADY INTEND TO GET THIS GAME, IT'S BETTER TO EXPERIENCE IT YOURSELF--  You see Conway just getting his Hypertrousers from the mail, the device he wears that allows him to leap at incredible heights as mentioned earlier, and a note on them reads that they are not to be used indoors. He immediately tries them inside his appartment and flings himself out of his window, and into the window to the lobby of the building next door. He receieves a call from the person inside the building, saying they were about to call him about a job and think they just saw him get thrown out of his window. Conway shrugs it off and says to let him upstairs, but as you go upstairs you see a suspicious character creep out of a door and shoot the person in the building before throwing them out the window and dashing away. __ Rating This game is great on all accounts. It welcomes several different playstyles, whether you like more aggresive or stealthy ones. The story is incredibly strong and at times silly, guaranteed to keep your attention, but if you like you can ignore it entirely. The game combines action elements with puzzle elements and allows to think about the actions you take, and the ability to restart if you die just seconds back allows for lots of experimenting and trial-and-error. It includes a scoring system for those of you who enjoy getting more points than your friends. It even has a level editor and workshop compatibility if you're so inclined.Overall it is a very, very fun game and the biggest critisism I have is that is ended so soon. I truly do wish for a sequel or even DLC. I'm quite literally wishing for DLC, that's how much I want more of this game. Gameplay: 5/5Story: 5/5Replayability: 4/5 That's an overall average of about 4.65/5. I would tell anyone to buy this game. It's a real gem.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
Gunpoint : ReviewGunpoint is a game I truly love to call 'Beauty'. It's fast paced, or slow paced (if you're that kind of person) adventure stealth 'em up. There is so much this game gets right, it's just a purely amazing bit of fun, and for $10, why not try it?ProsReally tight gameplayHilarious dialogueGreat puzzle designHyper trowsersConsStory is a little shallow at times.Defintely not a game for everyoneSummaryGunpoint is a stealth based adventure game based off of an agent who was framed for a crime. Or did he commit it the crime? Or was the camera wrong? Honestly, I don't remember. And that's it's one problem I seem to have with it, it's not very memorable. A great game nevertheless. I always found myself enjoying my time. And the ending is really quite a nice summary of what happened during the events of the game. I played this game mainly offline so it only shows 4 hours of gameplay on this account, but I got roughly 15 hours of gameplay out of it and there's still content I've missed.In short, I recommened this game to most gamers, some may not like it and they can have their reasons. But on a technical level, it's near flawless. If you're looking for about 15+ hours of fun and have $10 lying around, I'd definitely recommened this.Final rating: 8/10

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Ah Gunpoint.      Let's start out with the negatives of this game: It's too damned short.Roughly 20 missions, most of which can be beaten in less than 5 minutes, can result in a very short game. I only wish that there was a workshop for this game so that the level editors that MAKE levels can be more easily seen, subscribed, and then played.As for the game itself let's get down to the bare bones.I don't think I've ever played a game like this. In Gunpoint you are able to cross wires remotely and as a result- different things cause different things. E.x: A switch turns off a door- you rewire it to open a door- and that door can be rewired to open another door and so on, and so on. That is an amazing system than can be easily abused in a fun way.     Now for the enemies. There are 2 forms of enemies encountered in Gunpoint- normal guards, and enforcers.Normal guards are easy to deal with; pouncing on them being the most common way of dealing with them.Enforcers are more deadly forms of guard that cannot be pounced, so you have to use more stealth and wit to either take these guys down, or avoid them entirely.The fun part about taking down each enemy has it's own special feel.When you take down a normal guard and bash his face in for the second...third... fourth.... 300th time in a row, it kinda gives a sense of brutal joy out of it.When you take down an enforcer; either by electrocuting them, or knocking them out of a window- you gain a certain sense of accomplishment of taking down a non-pouncable enemy.The upgrades in Gunpoint are nice and very useful, especially after the story is well and done- so you can see how far you've come along ever since the start of the game.Now for the more artsy fartsy aspect of the game.The game itself is a pixleated, and for this game, I don't there there would be a better way to portray this game.It's simplistic, and get's the job done. A lot of dark tones of the surrounding city, bright insides to show contrast. The environment of the game is well done.The music- oh the music! It's  from cool jazz to an electronic feel, and that's a beautiful mixture in this game.You may or may not notice it when playing, but it's there- and it sets the tone for the game.The story itself is very short, and I am not going to give anyone any spoilers.Story is thought out, and executed as the basis of why you are in the levels you are.If it had a lot more levels, I would like it much much more.Overall 9/10 for the price, try the demo if you are uncertain if you want to buy this game or not.I'm looking forward to what other games Suspicious Developments makes in the future.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
												Gunpoint's title does it a slight disservice. In no way is this game the pixelated platform shooter that images and its title art may make it seem. Instead, it's a crafty, awesomly mechanical stealth puzzle game that's easy to pick up and play that feels genuinely rewarding when you're able to clear out missions in your own ways with whatever gadgets and power-ups you may have. The main mechanics are your super jumpy hyper trousers and the ability to re-wire the electrical circuits in every building. The former provides fantastic mobility, letting you launch yourself like a dart at enemies, through windows, and land safely from any ridiculous height you can reach.  The latter is how you'll spend a lot of your time working your way through the game's puzzles. With the crosslink ability you'll be hooking up light switches to open doors, security cameras to call elevators, and a number of other fun and easy to execute chain of events. Your creativity and the ease of how all these mechanics work is really what sells the gameplay and makes it fascinating. The game's only real bump is the relatively short playtime. Depending on your ability to quickly assess every situation, you could finish the game in as little as three hours, but honestly the mechanics are top notch and satisfying and the narrative intriguing enough to make this worth a play even at its current price point. Get it, it's fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												"22 dead. 36 injured. 20 jobs. $13,000. The week echoed in my mind like a gunshot in an empty street..They don't let me name names on this blog, but the person behind the hit I was investigating is dead now.He played a dangerous game: insulting my hat.The trigger man's dead. I thought that would feel good, but there's no escaping what it cost.I don't know.I think I picked the right side.Maybe that doesn't matter. Maybe all that matters is justice.Either way, I need to get out of this city."Probably the best indie game I have ever played, it's made by two people (Tom and John). When you finish the game, you get to pick some quotes and depending on how you play the game, you make kind of a paragraph (See Above). Anyways this game doesn't limit you to kill someone in only one way, you can be stealthy and go right by people, or pin them down to the ground and punch them 37 times in the face, or throw them out of a 7-story window. In Gunpoint, you can rewire electronics (Doors, buttons, switches, etc.), for example, you can rewire a switch so instead of turning off and on the lights, you can make it activate a power outlet and electrocute an enemy. Also, the game has a hilarious sense of (dark) humor when you are talking with the people who hire you to do the jobs. I recommend this game to anyone, no matter their gaming interests.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												It's a pretty short game. You can bum rush through the story mode in a couple of hours and unlock all the achievements pretty easily. Thanks to the level editor and the Steam Workshop support, though, the replay value is infinite. The autosave feature is pretty much essential, since, at least on my system, the game crashes every now and then. You can play the game with a certain degree of freedom, and at the end you'll be judged for your performance: the grades and titles you'll receive have no repercussion on the game's mechanics and development, they are just for show.If you enjoy puzzle games with a bit of action and the opportunity to make your own levels and share them, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
												Gunpoint's title does it a slight disservice. In no way is this game the pixelated platform shooter that images and its title art may make it seem. Instead, it's a crafty, awesomly mechanical stealth puzzle game that's easy to pick up and play that feels genuinely rewarding when you're able to clear out missions in your own ways with whatever gadgets and power-ups you may have. The main mechanics are your super jumpy hyper trousers and the ability to re-wire the electrical circuits in every building. The former provides fantastic mobility, letting you launch yourself like a dart at enemies, through windows, and land safely from any ridiculous height you can reach.  The latter is how you'll spend a lot of your time working your way through the game's puzzles. With the crosslink ability you'll be hooking up light switches to open doors, security cameras to call elevators, and a number of other fun and easy to execute chain of events. Your creativity and the ease of how all these mechanics work is really what sells the gameplay and makes it fascinating. The game's only real bump is the relatively short playtime. Depending on your ability to quickly assess every situation, you could finish the game in as little as three hours, but honestly the mechanics are top notch and satisfying and the narrative intriguing enough to make this worth a play even at its current price point. Get it, it's fun.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												"22 dead. 36 injured. 20 jobs. $13,000. The week echoed in my mind like a gunshot in an empty street..They don't let me name names on this blog, but the person behind the hit I was investigating is dead now.He played a dangerous game: insulting my hat.The trigger man's dead. I thought that would feel good, but there's no escaping what it cost.I don't know.I think I picked the right side.Maybe that doesn't matter. Maybe all that matters is justice.Either way, I need to get out of this city."Probably the best indie game I have ever played, it's made by two people (Tom and John). When you finish the game, you get to pick some quotes and depending on how you play the game, you make kind of a paragraph (See Above). Anyways this game doesn't limit you to kill someone in only one way, you can be stealthy and go right by people, or pin them down to the ground and punch them 37 times in the face, or throw them out of a 7-story window. In Gunpoint, you can rewire electronics (Doors, buttons, switches, etc.), for example, you can rewire a switch so instead of turning off and on the lights, you can make it activate a power outlet and electrocute an enemy. Also, the game has a hilarious sense of (dark) humor when you are talking with the people who hire you to do the jobs. I recommend this game to anyone, no matter their gaming interests.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Gunpoint is a a solid little stealth platformer puzzle game. You control a spy-for-hire who sneaks into various buildings to steal items or hack information. The game eases you into the systems at a steady pace, with the complexity ramping up nicely. There's also an interesting assortment of upgrades that give you various advantages like increased stealth or stronger abilities.The music is pretty perfect for the gameply, sorta jazzy but with a Mission Impossible/Oceans Eleven feel to it. The graphics are retro but plenty serviceable, with everything important to gameplay easy to discern. And it also has a pretty good sense of humor in the between mission dialogue and achievements.Only downfall is the whole game can be completed in about four hours, but there's some replayability, as it's pretty clear there are at least two endings, and plenty of different achievements for doing missions perfectly and using all the abilities to their maximum potential. I'd had this one in my library for quite a while and finally got around to playing it, and I'm glad I did. If you're considering it but on the fence, let this be your endorsement from a fellow former fence-sitter.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Gunpoint takes sneaking around to an interesting new extreme by redefining what normally distinguishes one stealthy action game from another (this being the tools you use to make not being seen easier) and gives you the wiring of the entire building to play with. Fundamentally, Gunpoint is fun for the same reason the first two Thief games were fun; the levels are extremely non-linear, and your goal typically consists of "get the room being pointed out, then get out as un-harassed as possible."The store page hype claims that you can rewire electrical sockets and enemy pistols, but these functions are only unlocked by limited use gadgets which become available after several missions are played. The majority of the gameplay experience consists of figuring out what daisy-chain of lightswitches, doors, and elevator call buttons will clear a path through the building and keep you out of the security guards' sight. This can become tedious and a little formulaic after a while, though it isn't enough to make me stop playing.The story is fairly good if you enjoy sarcastic comedy, but wouldn't be quite enough to give the game a shining recommendation on its own. Gunpoint's gameplay is more than enough fun to overcome any of these fairly minor shortcomings, though, and this is a double recommendation for anyone who played a great deal of Splinter Cell, Tenchu, and/or Thief in the early parts of these respective series.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												While it wasn't really a long game, Gunpoint is a memorable game with some interesting and fun gameplay. Playing as a private contractor with some pants that make you jump really high, you're at the wrong place at the wrong time and you have to prove your innocence and deal with the aftermath of what you did to prove your innocence. There's some light RPG elements that change things up, namely different upgrade paths, dialogue choices, and, towards the end, choosing one of two paths that help resolve the story in their own way.Toss in a level editor with maps you can get on the workshop, a customizable blog post at the very end, and some funny dialogue here and there, Gunpoint has some replayability after you finish the story, whether it's major or minor, however, I cannot say. 8/10, you should get this game eventually, whether you get it right now or during a sale, that's up to you.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Gunpoint is a good blend of a smart story, light puzzles, occasional humor, and almost-deaf guards with superhuman sight and reflexes in which you must steal (and optionally destroy the video surveillance) which can either acquit or convict George Zimmerman. Perhaps its because of the pixel art, but I want to draw parallels between this and Monaco, another game which continually occupies a significantly percentage of my consiousness. I am not even certain it is reasonable to try to draw a parallel, but emotions are running hot and baby ain't nothing going to stop this steam engine. They're not similar in the gameplay so much, which are actually quite different from one another, so much as the atmosphere and theme which evoked similar feelings. They both share the mechanics of guards and security cameras and the ability to hack the environment. But the short story is that Monaco is almost impossible to top. The puzzles in gunpoint are never very hard, but stopping for a moment to analyze the situation does unfortunately pull you out of the action. Not every meal needs to be tenderloin in a mushroom pan sauce. Sometimes a good juicy burger is all you need.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Gunpoint is a stealth-based puzzle-platform game. You play as Richard Conway, a freelance spy in a noir themed world. You were in the wrong place at the wrong time, and have been framed for murder. You must go through numerous levels to find out who framed you, and clear your name. The gameplay is great. You have a gadget called the "crosslink". It is used to rewire circuits in any way you wish. From basic changes such as making a light switch open a door, to causing an elevator to switch off the lights, making a guard walk through a booby trapped door, and having it slam in his face. The combinations are endless. The game is very much stealth focused. Confrontation with a guard will quickly result in your death. But this does not mean you cannot sneak up on everyone and beat them to death. You can get through levels silently, with no witnesses. Or you could rush through and make sure no one is left breathing to be a witness. You have multiple other gadgets to utilize too. Conway wears no ordinary trousers. They are spring loaded allowing him to jump great distances. His trenchcoat allows him to survive a fall from high distances. There is also an upgrade system which allows you to buy new gadgets, and improve already purchased ones. The story is great. The dialogue is incredibly funny, and the characters brilliantly wrote. The game also has an absolutely superb soundtrack. One of my favourite in any video game. You can check it out for free here[gunpointgame.bandcamp.com].The average time for completion is about 2-3 hours. So if you are looking for a short game to pass time, this is definitely one to consider. With multiple dialogue options, and plenty of achievements to earn, the replayability is great too. Gunpoint is easily my 2013 Game of the Year. I absolutely recommend this to anyone and everyone.Edit: As of some date a few days ago, workshop has now been integrated into the game. You can now browse from hundreds of user-created levels, adding hours more fun to the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												                                                                                 2D Watch_Dogs                                                                                      GunpointGunpoint is one of the most rewarding and exciting games I have played in quite awhile. The game has beautiful pixel art, well done background music, and challenging puzzles.Presentation:     In Gunpoint, you play the role of a freelance detective/secret agent. This means you take the jobs YOU want and get paid accordingly. Because of this, you can beat the game and never see some levels! Also, this concecpt is introduced in a really unique way. Everything is done over texts, and you choose how to communicate. You can lie, tell the truth, or cover up your tracks. The game also has a suprisingly good story. The writing is clever, and well done.9/10Sound:     Gunpoint has great music that I was happy to hear. The music matches the game's tone and feel and really complements it. Unfortunately, if I ever got stuck on a stage, the music did get a little repititious. The sound effects in the game are perfect and feel perfect.7/10Graphics:     The graphics is perfectly done pixel art. Nuf said.10/10Gameplay:     This is where Gunpoint shines. The actual gameplay is Gunpoint is absolutely amazing! I had genuine fun all through the game (excpept for a bug at the end which made me have to restart the level multiple times) even when I lost. The goal of the game is usually to either grab some prototype weapon or hack a computer then leave. How you do that, can be achieved in multiple ways. You could be a merciless killer and destroy everyone in your path, or you could flip lights off and sneak through the given building. A major point that I must mention on hacking. The hacking (or better called as in the game "rewiring") can be confusing at first but gets really cool. You can rewire a light switch so when the switch is hit, a trap door opens that sends a guard to his doom, for example. With all these great gameplay elements, I have little complaints with Gunpoint. The one knockoff, however, is how short the game is. The only reason I am not slamming Gunpoint for the short campaign is because there are levels I haven't even played because of my desicions. So I am just gonna replay the game!10/10Lasting Appeal:     As stated above, the campaign is great, but short lived. The game does come with a level editor, but it feels somewhat limited. The level editor is great, don't get me wrong, but it is simply not the focus of the game.8/10Verdict:Gunpoint is an amazing stealth adventure game that sadly ends way too early.+ Great Story                                                          - Short lived fun+ Fun Gameplay                                                     - Simple level editor+ Spectacular audio and visualsI hope this review helps :D

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I LOVE THIS GAME!!! I went on a spending spree with $30 on steam during the holidays and bought all of the retro games that were on sale. In my spree, I picked up Gunpoint after being satisfied with the demo I had downloaded. This game has delivered. It makes you think, it's full of action, and there are so many ways to tackle a mission (loud,guns,sneak,non-lethal,powergrid shut-down,etc.). Point being, this game is worth the $4 I payed for it, heck its worth more than that. With all of the new map creating features on the way and enjoyable campaign, this game can sell itself. So go try the demo, NOW! You have nothing to lose.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												Gunpoint is a brilliantly designed platformer that simultaneously makes you feel like a badass hacker, super spy, and gumshoe detective all at once. The best part of this game has to be Tom Francis' GREAT sense of humor that comes out in the speech choices and mission dialogue delivered through your smart device.  You can really go at your own pace during all of these missions and have a lot of fun sort of solving the puzzle of the buildings' electronics setps.  And you don't have to fret over dying much, as you have the option to reload X amount of seconds earlier upon dying to keep gameplay going.  I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Watch_Dogs 2 The Pre-Sequel lives up to its hype and more. It keeps the fun of seeing into the personal lives of strangers and wielding tech to slaughter anyone in your path from the original game. While still making the environment feel that it took place before the first game with an insane downgrade of graphics and a more arcade feel more similar to Pong and Space Invaders.Gameplay: Pretty sick, old fun from original game, maybe less but who knowsStory: Seemed average, honestly didn't pay attention as I was focused on acheievementsGraphics: Comparing the "new" and "updated" graphics of this game from its predecessor, I can't help but wonder what     Ubisoft was smokingEngine: I had some minor lag problems from time to time in this game, unlike the original which ran smoothly and beautifully, though not surprising considering this second game is newerOverall: 9/10 feels new and old at the same time! Can't wait for the next Watch_Dogs!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												This game is a great fun couple of hours. The fun is in the approach. You can go in gun (once acquired) or fists blazing, grab the objective and get out, or you can work out your perfect stealth infiltration and exit plan. With a light film noir feel, it looks and sounds nice, with a good compact story to boot. Reminiscent of Hitman games, you are graded after missions with regards to whether you were seen, used aggression, caused noise, as well as time taken. You can run through the story very quickly but half the fun is in trying to get the perfect A+ grade. Could easily have new story expansions for SP in DLCs and could suit a MP style (perhaps like a side-on version of Monaco) in future updates.

												Gunpoint is a stealth-based puzzle-platform video game created by indie developer Tom Francis.The game is set in the near future and sees players assume the role of freelance spy Richard Conway, who is tasked with infiltrating buildings to fulfil assignments from various clients. content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												+ Superb pixel art and characters+ Wonderful mechanics and level design+ Upgrades are fun and game changing+ Open world allows multiple solutions+ Plenty of humour in the text and action+ Good sound~ Short campaign (<2 hours) some replay value~ Some sections have single/limited solutions- Mostly uninteresting workshop levelsFor the sake of a double length campaign this would have been perfect.. in lieu of that it would have been great if users could have made campaigns instead of individual levels. But i cant take away the joy of this game having played it through twice (well four times as both times I did speed runs afterwards to get all A's).Conclusion: 7/10. Fun while it lasts.
